Entry.1:
(1)

A long day, and a move forward. Roads of traffick, and all the colours of the A.I.F. about. Lorries and guns, limbers and wagons, men moving up and passing down, and at slow intervals Ambulance Cars. Prisoners passing and passing, and in amongst empty wagons and limbers, a mounted convoy of Boche – of ammunition limbers, passing down with the stream to the rear.

All objectives and passed, at Franvillers a Corps H.Q. captured, and strange tales of tanks and planes and armoured cars come down. Midnight, to turn in.

August 10

2.

Yesterday a day of Maps "at the toot". Midday today sees the final objective of yesterday’s maps and stunt attained.

Now the development is to war.

August 11

3.

Roads deep, the dust and haze of red dead powder. Over the burnt brown of faces and arms, powdering that accentuates the beauty of features and colour, and makes doubly brilliant the clear quick eyes.

Attacking still and following up.

August 11

4.

A white road in the sun, with the smoke of dust from it, swings round the low hill and behind it: overshadowed by a high darkly wooded horizon edging a tremendous sky. The sun burning gold.

Tonight Frank D. tells of Ridge wounded again, and again an abdominal, Groves too, he in the neck: they both may die. Wounded also, but slightly, McCrae and Vin Cellars.

The Ambulance running an Advance Walking wounded D.S. about Harbonnieres.

All through the night bombing and shelling – a galloping repeating of all rembered of Keats and Brooke and Watson.

Poor Villers Bretonneux!

August 17

5.

Southgate

The fourth day wasted. At tomorrow for Ely, then for Cambridge – Winchester and Bristol. Elsie’s with child so I’ll not see her.

Left V.B. on morning of 12th.

August 18

Ely

Alone at last on the train with a damnable dirty-nailed Cockney, she flung her ultimate bait – "I was aht wiv an whorestralian last week in Finsbury Park". I read Alice Meynell.

7.

At the Lamb Hotel, so now out to see the Cathedral. Later. Back from a strolling as a stared at novelty, obviously I intrude – the hats a damnation – hardly a crown. But early in the morning I’ll forget these Englanders and myself in an ecstasy of stained glass, old carven stone, and lovely groupings, then to Cambridge.

A letter written to Mrs. H.

8.

By and about the Cathedral, comely old houses, richly mellowed colours of red and brown and grey and blue, vine grown, and gardened with tall flowering hollyhock rising above their walls, narrow gothick windows, small geometrical leaded panes. The curtains are imitation lace, and covering two old windows the back of a cheap near yellow dressing table.

They cannot love beauty: in the Albert and Victoria Museum on Friday, the splendid

torso of Serbia’s old hero by Mestrovic, stands between – and flanked – by tall wide covering show cases. You may look at it from angles – not further than four paces.

At Kensington that afternoon bought Alice Meynell’s Collected Poems – the 1st edition 7/6, saw there Hodgson’s "Poems" at 10/- and Daisies at 8/6. 8 o’clock, to dinner.

August 20

Southgate
Entry.2:
The great charm of people consists in not knowing them, another day wasted – a sacrifice to a sentimental laden pleasure.

Tomorrow I’ll partie – throw the remainder of my leave in the lap of the Gods – and sip Brandy & soda.

Damn! I’ll to Bristol tonight.

August 23

Bath
Entry.3:
Two nights and one day with an N.Z. M.G., then a casual parting, he to Cornwall, I to Bath. One full day of leave that life came into and laughter, now I am dead. Yesterday at Bristol will be the memory of this leave. We were looking for rooms when we met, we joined forces, and at 10 found beds at the Y.M.C.A. Then a morning about Bristol and Clifton, driving through a country full of home colour and form, and now a loneliness in a lovely town, and a dull pain at the heart and a vague fear of the night.

Tomorrow ? perhaps to Salisbury, perhaps to Winchester, then London – cold dead rouged London – and Southgate and France, to the little wrecked villages, where dumb wide-eyes ghosts go passing – where the deep night silences are broken by the far away gun beats, and by the sudden smashing of H.V. shells.
Entry.4:
Southgate

11.

Early this afternoon back here to Aunt Louie’s, now alone in the house, they all at church, I excused myself – in the face of "I do wish you were coming with me dear boy!"

Ted Ridgeway is dead. God what useless wastings. Tonight’s special paper tells in headings –

"Still advancing N of the Somme", "Haig’s men take Contralmaison & other positions", "Nearer to Bapaume", and Ridge is dead.

August 25

Bath left midday yesterday – in a hatred of damned "Anzacs". Three Australians and myself in uniform, four in hospital blues: and three Anzacs – each in size a match for the lot of us, to demand our passes and criticise dress.

Tea last night with a 6th Btn. lad – wounded on the
Entry.5: and yesterday commencing his 14 days leave.
Entry.6:
Tuesday, then France. Tomorrow I’ll to Kensington again and worship Mestrovic’s "Torso", and Rodin’s Bronzes. The two experiences of this leave have been the first seeing of a folio of plates & Mestrovic’s sculpture, and the damnably placed "Torso", and at Bath a half dozen portraits by Agustus Johns – in particular a strong viciously modelled girl’s face – expressioned horribly but fascinating and wearing a black white-feathered hat.

For two days now I have been listless and dead, bored unutterably & hot and cold by turns. If tomorrow the same I’ll to Horseferry Road.
Entry.8:
Night, and back again with "Maps". In the long treed square a good band played an hour, to a full audience of diggers, with stray Jocks and Tommies.

A smashed Town with its Abbey towers scared and broken, and all about the threading streets only Kharki, and the colour patches of three divisions, but by the splendour of their life and their country they have made Corbie lovelier far than red-rouged London.

A great arguing tonight with Jim S. over the genius of Agustus John but then Jim has not seen his portrait studies – only a few of his early drawings, so he compares him with the charlatan Epstein.

Mail accommodations , letters from Mother to end of June, one from Max P., two from Mrs. H. and from T.B.C., two L.S. Dysons new Cartoons, Sassoon’s "Counter Attack", Balzac’s "Catherine de Medici and Yeat’s Essays and "Folly" of T. Maynard. But its bed before diarying and a reading of the adventures of "Sylvia Scarlett".
Entry.10: Amongst the colours in the square last night, the blue and brown of the 43rd: so I asked one of Jake’s whereabouts, learnt he was at an O.T.C. and that Doug had died of his wounds after the Hamel stunt. A night at Wimereux before we left one another Jake once said, "Well I don’t suppose the three of us will come through" – and as the elder his was to be the sacrifice: and since then his luck has carried him past three woundings.
Entry.11: Victoria left at 8 in the morning of the
Entry.12: Folkstone at 4 in the afternoon, Boulogne at 7 on the
Entry.13:
morning, and Corbie detrained at 4 a.m. yesterday.

The Division are out, but there’s still warr before them, and within the next few days. Maps quiet.

On
Entry.14:
up to Harefield and had small growth cut from behind nose, a motor ride back to London completed cure of the long terrible dopiness.

15.

Afternoon: part of the morning passed sketching from the sq. a part of the Cathedral Abbey.

August 31

Yesterday’s mail: 

From Mother June 2nd, "Geoff came down on Wednesday and brought over 400 sheep to market: and to my surprise he enlisted on Thursday. I really felt very upset at first, but after thought I came to the conclusion I’d do the same if I were I his place."
Entry.15:
"Geoff, arrived home yesterday in dungarees: and such dungarees – the sleeves about a yard wide and pants in proportion! He hopes to get his proper uniform next week. We are going to try hard and get him his wings in the F.C., so if you meet the kid, salute him, eh?"

But the letter of June 2 follows on with a note on books and buying, and a wonder at Rebel Song and the Irish. Damn! but it’s a dear letter, and the earnestness behind it would make me foreswear books, only, there are much easier ways of suicide. But I’ll draw a limit for a while, and read Balzac in Everymans and the cheap reprints of the old lauded classics.

The sun’s coming out and a skys clearing of clouds: by in the canal, green water between ruled banks. so to the lagoon.
Entry.16:
16.

Passing the staircase, through a jagged shell hole in the wall, a tangling of dark branches, red flower laden, over a gleaming green space of water, reflecting a white dissolving venus, by a hessioned latrine.

Jim S. is painting an interior of the Abbey, his easel against the smashed altar: the best of his late work is a bridge over the stream by Aubigney : the usual distortion of his perspective is absent, and the impotent daubing of his colour, has confirmed the richness of the stream’s banks colouring. Its his most successful sketch.
Entry.17:
The argument is the old one, of Tommy officers and Australian. Geoff, Sam, Ken, with occasional quiet comments by Tom. Geoff on the "superiority" of the Australians – "I give it to you they are the finest troops: they have had 500 miles of front for near three years!"

 word is still good – though today have passed Divvy Ambulances following Ambulances and lorries of slightly wounded. Kemmel is ours and Bailleul. And from The Times of 29, the pasting of the facing page, so the dull rumours of last April – or March? – 
are
 were lying.

Times
Entry.18:
Australian Graves at Pozieres

War-scarred Cemeteries Regained.

Mr. C.E.W. Bean, Official Correspondent with the Australians in France, in a message recording the recapture of Pozieres, stormed by the Australians in the Somme battle of 1916, says:-

Crosses and graves stand on Pozieres summit exactly as they were before the great offensive of last March passed over them. Scars of battle mark almost every monument, but the cemeteries, so far as we could see, had been scrupulously respected. The cross of the seventh field company of the Australian Engineers is nearly cut through by a shell, but still rises over the Canadian and Australian graveyard on the hill. The great white crosses of the first Australian Division, eighth Australian Battalion, stand scarred with shrapnel in the cemetery near the entrance of the village. Before them to-day are two newer rows of German graves. The cross of the fourth Australian Battalion still stands in the little line of scrub from which the battle started, with the cross of the
Entry.19: Battalion beside it. The grave of Captain Margetts, of the
Entry.20:
Battalion, is still marked by a small white cross beside the stumps of the copse where he fell.

By the windmill still stands the dark wooden cross of the second Australian division on the summit of the whole Somme battlefield. Heavy shells have shaken this cross half loose from its stone pyramid, but it still rises there beside the great road on the hilltop, which the second Division won. Beside it the north and south lines of the old O.G. trenches, along the summit, can still be traced by small white crosses to nameless Australians, with here and there the grave marked with the name of the 46th Battalion and other battalions, which two years ago were fighting on that terrile hillcrest.
Entry.23:
The first drafting since leaving Villers Bretonneux. Sullen clouds over the blue of the sky, and a white haze from the sun behind them. This morning a walking along the canal – and springboards everywhere: but a cold wind over the water holds bathing. 

Cabled this morning for £15 and the letters still to write explaining it and answering that of
Entry.24:
Damn! Why didn’t I have my account made to the London Commonwealth Branch, then there’d have been no worrying by Mother, and the peace of knowing the rock you stand on.

19.

Between the two long captured guns in the square, a ‘shelter’ gun, mounted on perambulator wheels, part of an old plough, part of a hand press, and a length of thick iron piping. Captured by Chinese Labour Corps addressed to Pekin War Records.

September 3, 4

20.

Tonight to the "Kookaburras" – the 5th Divvy C.P., a poor show with a finale of a Cockney’s Joy Ride designed by Agustus Johns, well designed but badly executed.

Must get hold of new pen, this belongs to either Ken or Ted, mine a broken wreck from the losing of many windings of plaster.

The warr still waging, now the Canadians doing well from Arras towards Cambrai.

Met Horsewell by the stream during the afternoon, he in the 15th, out just now with three others guarding Kits with the 2nd.

A day of rain and sun patching: sun in the afternoon brought out the swimmers but the water cold as ice.

Enjoyed the reading of J.B. Yeats essay on "Synge" and "Butler" and his book of newly published "Essays".

September 4

21.

Tonight drawn unwillingly, but with no chance of escaping, into a dull argumenting with a "man who knows what I like, and I hate pedantic red tape" on the beauties of Corbie Abbey. Last year from the train passing to Amiens, Corbie always attracted – a great Cathedral seemed to loom richly above the villiage: but I always passed on to Amiens. This year comes the spoiling of the old impression: the shell wrecked Abbey is a soulless building, barstard in its design, building and decoration. Tonight, that the fine old Church of St. Vaast of Bailleul was good, where Corbie Abbey is bad would not appeal to the 11th Btn’s observer, and back at Maps, with the remainder of the observers, collectively they desired the confirming of their appreciation of this dull ruin’s "beauty".

And comes the wonder if later I’ll be able to attempt the convincing of clients just what is good and bad in design! God! there’ll be all the women of Surburbia, the so artistic women, to listen to smiling, while they give their compleat and artistic "ghutz" of their £1000 Villa desires!!

And the folio of Mestrovic’s sculpture comes to mind: give me the clay and I’ll model, is there a chance?

Beyond books, beyond everything sculpture and full nakedness appeal.

September 4

Today came to the pool-stream the Engineer of Sylvestre, and his image has been in my brain since. So few others – Jake, and his thigh has been laid open. Frank Hungerford, and seeing him last month at Allonville he has lost his old condition. Tommy Walker ? his beauty is too plausible – there is falsity somewhere. Eric ? he’s dead, and Doug Roach too.

If an After is, it’ll be of sculpture, wine growing or Architecture, and if it’s the last, the prayer is that it will be with Vin, him to charm by his compleat agreement the damned parvenus’ appreciations. I’ll be drawn into more of these fruitless word battles, "the illiterates!"
Entry.25:
22.

Summer in the day: full colour skies, and heaping galleon clouds. Late morning to the white café by the canal and swimming. In front of the "White Café" a doorless, windowless café now, a long narrow treacherous springboard, balanced over a long sideboard flush with the bank, and anchored by a great fragment of a brick pier, and this afternoon to the stream as it runs through an orchard, before it reaches the ruined factory. Back to H.Q. met Jim S. on one of the garden seats raging at a latrine butting between an old stone venus and a great dull red tree, and Jim wanted to argue Blake’s inferiority as an Artist – I’d mentioned Yeats obvious admiration for his genius.

No argument.

23.

"Call for the Pioneers!" Now they’re re-slating our latticed-to-the-sky roof, weeding the rose gardens and clearing away from the balcony terrace the heapings of rock debris and timber.

Sent down to Eric G. "Sylvia Scarlett", must return too Basil’s copy of "Tragedy of a Genius".

Canadians still doing well – Henencourt Wood entered. The French have advanced deeply to Guiscard and a further advance by the 4th east of Peronne. And the Americans have still to be heard of.

September 6, 8

24.

A vivid sky and a burning sun: all day long bathers along the canal and in all the lagoons and streams.

A crowd gold in the sun and sun flecked in the shadows hail two hundred yards along the canal path an unladen postman. "Any letters?" – a head shake, and a chorus that follows the circle of sound – "You --- !"

The early afternoon on maps of Battle objectives: the 3rd and 5th Divns., we in support. And tonight comes the wire that after no battle our line runs by the plan’s second objective, and in towards Ham and Laon the French advancing.

We to move up: perhaps tomorrow.
Entry.26:
25.

Halle

Moving up, the sun behind leaden mist clouds, and the roads through grey and patched green country deep in fine dust.

Two lorries to move H.Q.’s staff, the greater part of its equipment, and a full guard.

The old Somme country of hills and valleys, and battled woods of stark broken 
poles
 stumps.

"Jove! how’d you like to charge that hill with y’ pack up!!" "Fix Bayonets: Charge!! Cock a Machine Gun over the top, and knock every barstard dead!" One of the 5th Btn.

Heavy rain in the afternoon, and clearing skies in the evening, with such colours of golden copper and misted mauve, blue and green, beyond understanding and with the last colour of the sun fringing yellow a great deep blue cloud, flares from the hills and valleys – Fritz flares of the diggers’ firing.

H.Q. parked hardly in an old patched farmhouse, and a dozen of us wondering on our place of sleeping: the attic – with a splintered and debrised floor and a roofing of ruberoid, full of sneezing gas! Eyes still stinging from a gazing about this afternoon.

The 1st to go in, supporting the 3rd and
Entry.28:
26.

The A.P.M. in the small corner Chapel: passing this morning, his white-lettered black board – A.P.M. beneath the Rising sun, like the black skull and thigh bones card these small villiage churches seem so well stacked with.

27.

From a captured letter written by man of 190 I.R. 220 Div. dated
Entry.29:
We are lying here in a hellish position, no dugouts, but all in funk holes, with losses & again losses, and dead, so that one almost becomes mad. Since lying here I have been smoked out three times, and if this still continues for long I shall cease to take part, you can be sure of that: for I am not hanging on so miserably here to get my limbs shot to pieces. We are not going out into rest. The orders are to hold the position till the last man, and the Coys go into line here with 20 mannikins. My God if the Tommies only knew that! Ah poor Germany!

In the 2nd Coy of 9th I.R., 28 "Div. prisonersinterrogated two days back, tells of the Company oil being of the warr being over in 4 or 5 weeks!!!

"Ah, Poor Germany!"

September 9

28.

After plans of three objective lines of an advancing on St. Quentin – 4th and 1st Divns., for a walk to Peronne. A city of great ruin: a city of ruin utterly dead, and still full of the most beastly and individual smell of Boche. The Church ruined as the Church of Bapaume – the aisle and naves filled high with heaped stones of tumbled columns and 
stones
 rubble of vaulted roofing. It has been before warr broke over it, a lovely church, a building of some achievement and of good design. The columns and wall of one aisle stand, and the apse walls and part of the High Altar. What a sketch! And shortly we move for Tincourt.

Walking back met one of the "Sentimental Blokes" of the Dranoutre stunt: a yarning of their show, and telling him of the Canadian "Dum Bells" their opening scene greatly appeals. Tried in a roundabout way – lauding the good taste of the Diggers, to work him into short piece by the good men – Barrie, Wilde and Shaw. But from beneath his assumption of "Diggerism" came out his "T.T. ness", so praised his introducing of the "Indian Love Lyric" stuff.

September 9

Down tonight to the 9th F.A. in hopes of seeing Bill Adams: but learn that since last Oct. he has been with the 2nd A.G.H. Bert R. up from the Amb. – Motor Orderly with Reg. D. A and B Bearers have gone up with the 1st Bde. Toby, Nick & Coy attached to one of the Btns.

No Mail: beyond the leave accumulated stuff, none since returning: so today posted to Smith of Paris 15F. for French’s two vols. of verse and poems in prose.

A sketch, commenced last night, finished of "Maps & G.".

29.

All about the trenches here, parties of salvagers, passing by Bray yesterday, parties of Fritzs – apparently alone, industriously carrying shells, M.G. Belts and all the Fields accommodation, to small roadside dumps.

Two T.T.’s their guard!

In his abandoned dugouts, and all about the probable billeting areas, he has as last year been leaving bogey traps and small mines. Why not use captured Boche as cleaners out of these doubtful two places?

History holds plenty of precedent to justify this.

September 10

30.

Epitaphs from Omar Khayham to a Tommy’s at La Boiselle – "He done his bit": but Scott tells of one in indelible over a half-buried Boche at Mt. St. Quentin –

"There lies a Hun who met a Digger!"

31.

"They’re calling the new reinforcements ‘The Stokers’"!

"Why the Stokers?"

" – They’ve kept the home fires burning!"

This contrib. from Mac.

32.

Afternoon with Ken and Jim across the fields – through the deep belts of the Boche old wiring and past isolated shell-hole graves of 2nd Div. men – to dead Peronne. An afternoon of clouds and passing showers and brief patching of a white sun. Made an unsatisfactory sketch from top of the heaped fallen columns and wall. Jim and Ken worked from a small high bay chapel; two rather good mates.

Yesterday Jim did St. Quentin: it passes my test – a sketch I’d like to own: taken from an old shelled trench the woods of the summit stand stark against a windy sky. In water colour its his best picture.

The Divisions go in tonight.
Entry.30:
33.

George defines Brasseries, as "the place where they make you show your photographs". Satire mostly of Butler – or the typical Digger.

George E. suggests a "Button Day" for H.Q. – but G. desires a Wattle Day – a "What’le y’ have day!" – and rum for miles around.

34.

A long yarning with Jim on painting etc., then Mac into the tale. Mac confesses a vague regret that he "didn’t give Art a fly – but when I was a kid I’d a sickening of paints – the Mater was mad on it – it was her mania. D’you know what she did at one house we were in? – painted every panel of all the doors with scenes an’ that! An’ I used to get some terrible hidings: over the wet paintings I rub my finger, an’ ask, "Mum is this wet?", an’ they’d go mad at me."

So a yarning ending pleasantly and so to turn in.

Mac away to Corps early in Oct.

September 11

35.

Bois de Buire

The Bagmen, H.Q. staff, Maps, and D.O. in a Bon Hut put up during the afternoon by the Engineers.

Amongst the Bagmen a new 2nd Btn. lad of fine build & features, and wounderful quiet grey eyes.

September 11

Casualties in the 4th Btn., a party of Boche surrendering, discover a party smaller in numbers to themselves, they commenced a stunting, and support came to infilade the 4th.

In the South the French have reached the Hindenburg Line – a good advance, and ground gained S. of St. Quentin.

In an instant, through the edge of the wood, a sky with the sun’s setting, of gold Siamese silk, and the silhouetted branches and leaves a rich vague green.
Entry.31:
36.

Rain, and the muffling of deep gun fire on the left; and a wind like the wash of the sea through the wet leaves of the trees.

Halle left at midday, and in lorries to the edge of the wood: past Peronne the stark stumps of trees and grey battle country fell away, and winding poor roads – a hundred Tommies labouring on their rebuilding – were through green meadows on hills and by valleys, and over the green horses of the 3rd Div. Artillery, with mounted stockmen passing amongst them and around. Sleeveless shirts, shorts and the slouch hat, and the sun
Entry.32:
gold on their burnt bodies.

37.

The afternoon across two valleys to an old gun position of the Boche: salved from there two of his shell-case return boxes for ‘Maps’ gear.

Jim tells tonight of a tale heard from two separate sources, of the Boche leaving at his abandoned Dressing Stations, dead bodies on stretchers, moving the stretcher explodes the mine!
Entry.33:
38.

No Mail, and a dull day of rain, clouds and passing sunshine but tonight, and the nights still young, two Boche raiders brought down in flames – as great giant flung gold burning torches, trailing tiny stars of light, and great floating exquisite flares of scarlett, green and pearl gleaming white, and the while a sky of darkling blue sparsely starr’d, divided and crossed with the white of searchlights. As the first plane flamed in the sky and fell, a great wave of cheering from the troops in the valley – and a wave of sound that swung round the wood and through it. And between the two planes firing, this through from Aust. Corps ..

"French and American troops have joined across the St. Mihiel Sailient, meeting at Vigneulles, A.A.A. Prisoners numbering 20,000 A.A.A. Mopping up of salient proceeding."

The guns loud all through last night, till well towards mid morning, but I.S. tells only of varying Artillery activity.

September 15

39.

Midday: Tom to lunch – Ted on his way to Australia, leaving here yesterday afternoon at an hour’s notice. Ken on his way to England, Len of the D.O’s and two Pioneer draftsmen compleating ‘Maps’. Yesterday on maps for the coming stunt – that will bring the 4th Divn. to within 1000 yards of Bellinglise – of Alan Seeger’s Sonnets.

A white sun morning, and a pale sky through the green undergrowth of the Hazels. Jim has been sketching in colour – and achieved but a vague imitation of the ‘pretty’ Christy!

Tried yesterday to get Vin down to fill Ted’s place – but Laughlin jibbed when he heard he was in the Transport.

And Laughlin this morning for Australia – via Italy: Brindisi.
Entry.34:
40.

Bob S. down from the Ambulance tonight, and just back from Paris leave, comes full of admiration for one Miss E.A. Rout – Hon. Sec. of N.Z. Volunteer Sisterhood, and staying at the Hotel d’Ostende, for reference, address, 9 Rue de la Michodiere.

September 16

41.

First mail for weeks, yesterday: and a ‘bonser’ letter from Betty – a letter all Australian, and two, July 7 and 14, from Mother. On the 14th Mother writes – "Geoff will know in about 3 weeks wether he will get through – for the A.F.C."

Two minutes ago the third of tonight’s raiders over and in a sky clear of searchlights till he’d dropped his load – about 15 small bombs.

Battle plans for 18th compleated since establishing here, on the General’s Maps.

September 17

42.

Today a letter to be written to Mother: but it should have been written on the 13th. It would be a far more beautiful custom if instead of receiving present son such a day presents were made to the Mother, this though is too obvious for such a world of unreason. 

In the black hours of the morning deep rain, thunder, lightning and a great wind through the trees – and shelling! What a night for the line Battalions – a night of old Flers over again. And tomorrow? But this morning a clear high pale sky, with passing thin whiffs of white mist, and the sun clear and drying.

A Pioneer found in a nearby won villiage, a fountain pen, uncapping it detonates a charge and his wounding bad.

43.

Afternoon: small ‘toot’ jobs – single copies of stunt maps: now a clear board.

A few evenings back the yarning came up of ‘Barstard’. George E. had some good tales, one of a Bishop: at the dressing of a Digger’s arm wound, feelingly he sympathised " – It’s a boody war lad!" The Digger looks up, and agreed: "Yes, it’s a 
barstard
 !"

The tales told too, of a pre-warr Methodist Padre, after a year’s Pardreing in France, going home to tell his people – "Over there they called me the "Old Barstard"! – the beam is imagined.

But the realist of all – this from an old Bulletin, explaining the origin of "Dear Mother" –

Dear Mother:

The £10 arrived, and they won’t give me leave to Cairo: Isn’t it a barstard!"

September 17

The hope is that a careful record will be made of these tales, of the pithy summing-up language of the troops: "Aussy" certainly will carry a fair record, and as far as it goes, is a good reflex of one of the aspects of Digger life, and the record should be of the slow growth of terse phrases. "Grout" came in slowly early in 1917, developed, and now is now part of daily use. "Gutzer" walked along the Duckboard track, and has developed to the weaker – ‘Abdominal’ – ‘Horizontal’ and ‘Crash’. But the simplest of them all, and only Australian is the beloved "Possy", to the Tommies its Bivvy, comfortable or uncomfortable: but to the Digger, ‘Possy’ in 9 cases of 10 stands for a crude Bivvy neatly camouflaged to the snug ‘Possy’. And the friendliest is "Dig", the Bulletin’s solid labour to make him ‘Bill Jim’ has been as avoided as their efforts to make ‘Australia’ "Anzalia"! ‘Aussy’ perhaps – though its first use by the Tommies seemed a veiled insult. Digger stands triumphant: ‘Cobber’ is good, but it lacks the clear, happy, ring of "Dig!" Damn! the very sound of it’s a laugh, and the visioning of gold or brown features & sapphire eyes!

September 17

44.

To turn in, with maps of the stunting fronts well arranged and ready: groups of red, brown, blue and green pencils, and skeleton maps. But the possibilities of such another high pressure morning as at V. Bretonneux on Aug. 9 are slight. Patrol reports of last night tell of one of his strong rearguard posts evacuated, & of fortifying work near our 2nd objective line.

September 18

45.

Evening

Slow, slow rain, and zero at 5.20, the sound of the gun barrage uneven and undecided. Then before 8 word of the first line being reached, and the battle commenced, and a lull in the news.

And at breakfast this from Corps,

Follows from 4th Army, torrid 8.15 A.A.A. Begins. A.A.A. Salonika front French and Serbian Troops combined in the attack yesterday, and are reported to have broken into Bulgarian positions to a depth of 7 km. on a front of 25 km., A.A.A. 4000 prisoners and 30 guns have been taken by the Allies, A.A.A. address all concerned A.A.A.

Came the slow smile, and a wonder at the useless worrying there’ll be over "Charlie boy" at Salonika in the A.S.C.

September 18

The 9th Bn. reached at 11 the line of exploitation within 2000 yards of Bellicourt. To 5 p.m. prisoners total well over 1000 excluding 45 officers.

From a Pioneer lad, heard an amusing account of the getting to the line of the ‘dummy’ tanks. Taken up on the L.R. at the end of the trip, a donk was roped to one – and bolted!

Jim back from a day forward brings a sketch of an old Boche M.G. position with its dead at their post: Templeux le Guerard in the distant cup of the rise, it is a good record, and in the class with "Mont St. Quentin". This yesterday’s oil, of the 1st Bn. Transport Cookhouse has a rather decent background, faintly in the manner of Phillips Fox, but its whole effect is poor.

In the afternoon down to Tincourt to the Pioneer Bn. with Harold B. – one of the new draftsmen. After the following days of work at the board, and with a white and blue patching sky, the country and its dotted copses and woods indescribably lovely, and behind the ruins of Buire a fringe of trees have already taken the colour of autumn. Passing one of the folds in the slow hills, a strung out line of rusted iron bivvys, and about on the clear green and in the sun, a hundred Pioneers fresh from line fatigues: in sleeveless shirts, wide open and in underpant shorts, shirtless, chatting, scraping putties & breeches, bunches yarning, & a hatless, sunburned, two-up school, and on the ridge by Cote Wood, on the horizon through the haze of the valley, occasional instant fountains of dull rose, fading to a passing cloud.

46.

To turn in, a day of no drafting, of waiting for the next wire. Most bring in totals of 1369 O.R. and 60 Officer prisoners to us: guns captured too, the attack an entire surprise. Wires from 3rd, 4th and
Entry.35: French Armies still to come in.
Entry.36:
47.

Back from the Amb. late last night George brought old mail, and a gem from Bett just before her Dubbo trip. Letters from Mother of
Entry.38: Today wrote to T.B.C. for Bennett’s "The Title", and announcement of T.L.S. – Barrie’s "Courage My Children" – four "Half Hour" Plays, Barbusse’s "We Others" and Fabre’s "Life of the Grasshopper".
Entry.39:
48

In the evening down to Tincourt to Pioneer Camp with Harold B. and a half hour yarning with Vin D. Across the valley guns on the far ridge, and shrapnel and flares – gold and white in the blue gloom of the far sky. Vin waiting on Blighty leave, and no arguing him towards Paris.

Tonight came into "Maps" one Lieut. of the Pioneers: one of Jim’s sketches drying, he admired which led to a bringing out of the "St. Quentin" and others. Then he spoke of Lindsay’s book, and tomorrow promises to bring it along for our appreciation. So it’s a looking forward to tomorrow – to the seeing of a book I’ll probably have to pay treble the published price for, & then for a soiled copy: Oh Damn! its as useless depending on Mother for these buyings as buying them in Buire.

Yesterday’s battle brings us 63 O: 1578 O.R.: 150 M.G.: 2 A.T. Rifles: 6 T.M.: 1 A.T. Gun: 1.8" How.: 7 5.9" How.: 10 4.2" How. and 16 .77 cm. guns. Since Aug. 8 the Armies captures reach 9770: 41750 O.R.: and the Corps of this took 541 O: 19900 O.R.
Entry.40:
49.

Early in the morning he brought to ‘Maps’ Lindsay’s Book of Pen Drawings, and all the day till plans of tonight’s stunt by 1st Bde. there’s been a mood of resentment on me. Damn, why didn’t I cable Angus instead of writing, yet the thin hope comes that perhaps after all they’ll have my copy ready. Apres. And it’s a book beautifully printed, wounderfully in advance of old pre-warr producing. It was a copy from Sydney Ure Smith to ? Phipson – the Pioneer Lieut. who brought it up.

No Mail.

In a grey sky and through a mist, the moon a faintly blue pearl, and a cold cold night, the trees still and beautiful against the even small clouded sky.

September 21

50.

This, from News Sheet No. 3 issued from Aust. Corps today.

The Journal des Debats says:-

"Britain’s greatness in this war has been her acceptance as severe but useful lessons of the inevitable set-backs at the start" … and goes on to say. "But there is something else even more striking than the attitude of her great autonomous colonies, who also spontaneously took up the common burden, a part which none would have dared to propose to them. To-day it is to the whole of the British Empire that honour is due, and the capital is proud to record and emphasize the immoral glory won by Canadians, Australians, New Zealanders, and all these young people whose democratic spirit is overflowing in a flood of heroism which they hardly understand themselves." – Reuter.

51.

Mail, a single letter from T.B.C., announcing their discovery of a Cuala edition of Lady Gregories Book of Saints and Wonders – "which if still available we could supply for 45/- plus postage. May we secure & send?"

Referred to C.W. Beaumont’s copy at 21/-.
Entry.41:
52.

Back from a walk across the grass land by the forest, above Tincourt and Buire, yarning with Geoff of the Division. Last night’s stunt – a success by us, but made a failure by the Boche surrendering to us and hardly fighting the 74th, following that of the 18th, broke the exaggerated promise final stunting .. 
Jan
 Dec. 17th and September quickly passing!

Today Tom turns down the six months Australia! Eric D. and Jack B. up from the unit, and leaving here tomorrow with Bobby S. and Sothers of the Ambulance. And Tom turns it down: so compleately obsessed becomes a man who surrenders entirely to his work!
Entry.42:
53.

Morning, sheets of boundaries: and in the afternoon Disposition plans of the sector taken over by regiment of the Americans. Tom’s had the wind up all the day, and quite uselessly, the maps still in the office and unneeded.

A Black night, and slow even rain: under the close Hazel undergrowth, soft faint music of drops falling from leaf to leaf, and a coolness and darkness full of a soothing benediction.

In Palestine, Gen. Allenby has taken over 18000 Turk prisoners, counting still.
Entry.43:
54.

To be relieved by 30th American Divn., now perhaps the full Corps rest is to begin.

Pasting from Anzac B. cover of Sept. 6, "Setting up a Light T.M. in a recently captured trench."

Jim back from Peronne, and by orders through a two star Lieut.

The hope is that the relieving ‘Murkans’ will attack: the Line they’re against from A.P.s is exceptionally strong & the Boche should make a good stand for it, but hell the location!
Entry.44:
Susanne

55.

In the Chateau – broken by warr’s passing – of the Marquis D’ Estournel: a great red-brick long chateau, on the flat of the valley, from above, on the wide road dipping to its main gate, a building that promises pleasure, and faintly recalls a note of Fontainebleau. But it’s the old pretentious disappointing chateau meaninglessly decorated and embellished, an interior of gaudily gilded and marbled galleries, panelling of rich-coloured and figured marble abutting painted plaster. The staircase of grey, black and rose-red marbles, and a ceiling of painted fat cherubs decending through a painted opening in a painted dome. Maps are on the landing by the G.O.C.’s room!

In a chapel of the Susanne church marbles from 1593 confirm the burial below of the family of the Marquis D’Estournel. The church is bare of all altars and plaster Saints: holes gape raggedly in the walls and roofing: the only sound is russelling breeze in dead leaves – old trees decorating some Boche celebrating.

The flooring of the chapel above the vault has been deliberately torn up and tiles in the centre of the altar steps: debris and bricks strewn. So a slab beneath the feet of a crucifix outside has been smashed away, and the vault of the D’Estournel opened.

"Bloody murdering barstard!"

"Ah, he’s a no-good barstard anytime!"

From their shelves great old coffins have been drawn, and smashed open, and, 
they
 from the vault the coffins were drawn and the bodies emptied to a heap: the lead of the old casing was melted and burn’d.

56.

With Harold, along the canal yesterday evening to the 18th Bn. The first well enjoyed walk since those of Courcellete-Quehen last December.

57.

Evening … By the Chateau there’s a long building of tall windows: by the large doorway a notice, "Boxing to-night": Inside, plaster walls shew pannelling for pictures, and over a tiled floor parts are uneven with dried horse dung, a rough-framed stage, and a maze of 18 pounder boxes, and in the room’s centre a large packing case: today it was lifted, and underneath an old black basalt tomb slab of the founder of the house of the D’Estournels, and his heiress .

September 25

Though horse dung and straw hide the fine carvings, the slab is richly designed and very beautiful. The case was placed over it by the 3rd Divn. party who had shown in the hall.

Always Division Guard is of finely built and burned men, but the present guard, of the 9th Bn. stands alone for smartness and beauty: one is the nearest approach to a Michael Angelo figure I’ve seen, a splendid giant built richly and 6’4".

58.

Noting a plan I was on, the A.P.M. intruding in Maps a day back, he casually mentioned, pointing across the boundaries of the Divn. and the 74th, "My men got a hell of a lot of prisoners from there!" I pointed out that it was beyond our boundary – "Yes: pinched them from the Tommies!".

And he and his "mess" all wear our uniform and Australia’s badges.
Entry.45:
Long

59.

Susanne left at 9 this morning, "Maps" and "G", and arrived at Long early in the afternoon. A small straggling villiage in the hill, to the valley of the Somme, we in the ‘Marie’.

September 26

60.

Some notes on the lorrying from Bois de Buire to Susanne, and to Long.

Salute to Nevison! passing Hermies and the primitive warr’d country came first appreciations of the war painting, "The Shepherd hears the Guns at Dawn", till the 24th was the only one of his I’d appreciated, but now comes the realisation of his success and his rich impressionism. At Hendersons on Charing Cross Road I passed his book only half seeing the casually turned pages.

Passing Mt. St. Quentin, a field of sudden bursting smoke bombs – bursts of blue smoke, and rich spraying of red gold and mauve patching, columns of smoke rising as clear chiselled clouds.

A Tommy Motor Ambulance, and there in front – clean shaven vacantly smirking faces: every while one would lift from behind a cushion a bottle of brandy, sip it and pass it to the others. Through the window to the car, four stretchers in the racks!

Crossing the valley – trench line crossing whitely, a road from Susanne to the Albert rd., trees of brown gold by its edge, rich with a vague green turning to yellow, and a terrific sky of pale milky blue.
Entry.46:
26, 27, 28

Albert – and the old squalor of its ruins gone, lost in a compleat wrecking of the whole city: even the church ruins have taken on a dignity, suggesting the ruin of a building of beauty, the collapse of the entire town explains this, and a further smashing of its walls and roofing.

Peasants amongst the drying grain, lately bringing in their crops, lately used trenches zagging through their fields: the harvesters old women, and two of them wearing vivid red bandannas.
Entry.47:
61.

The Americans attacking north of Verdun and along the line and prisoners numbering 10000 by the morning’s wire.
Entry.48:
62.

Blankets down, when Ken comes in with word of a message by phone from Corps of Passchendaele again ours, and a push commenced between Ypres and the sea, with 1500 prisoners as an Hors D’Oivire . Canadians within a mile of Cambrai, and prisoners to 10000 theirs and 200 guns. Americans and French still advancing in the south, and their prisoners now passing 20000.

Turning in last night the wire from Corps good too – of Bulgaria after a 24 hours armistice asking for peace – which was refused! Great arguments have been over the "after a 24 hours armistice": was an armistice granted? or was peace asked for after the refusing of an armistice? Today’s mail is equally ambiguous.

63.

Away after tea with Harold, and a walk following the Tow Path along the Canal to Pont Remy: awhile with Nane and Harry G. and Johnno, then with Les F. and Roby: so back to Long by 9.

Mail today, letters re-addressed from Harefield – from Geoff, Mother and another bonny yarning from Betty.

And a bill from T.B.C. 9148.

Tomorrow the Americans on our old front: Battle Instructions Series E, with General – in command and attachments from the Aust. Corps.

Tomorrow should end with tonight’s good word repeated.
Entry.49:
64.

From A.B. notice of Death of Sir G. Reid. A Philosophy of the whole army of ‘Diggers’. Americans doing well, Bullecourt & Nancy theirs.

Sir George Reid’s golden rule for the attainment of old age is worth a place in the Office Window as a corrective to all war valetudinarians: "I have aimed at health and happiness, and when confronted by a formidable obstacle I have first tried to knock it over; failing this, to get round it; if not, then under it; and if all these manoeuvres failed I have been content to lie down in its grateful shade, lauding it as a beautiful blessing in disguise."
Entry.50:
65.

Back from a yarning over Coffee at the Estaminet by the Hotel de Ville, and the wire of Armistice being signed with Bulgaria, and of hostilities ceasing at 12 noon today, and of our occupying stragetical points.

Today’s "Mail" tells of good advancing beyond Paschendaele by the Belgians and British, of the outskirts of Cambrai gained, and of slight advances by St. Quentin, wires from Corps have been nil, map altering from the "Daily Mail".

66.

At 9 last night along to McCubbin’s billet, and a yarning there of all that matters. A yarning of Johns, of Nevison and the Australian Artists, and of Beautiful Cities, and already Sydney has her squares ruined by bad buildings – by the Railway, the abortions of Joe Gardner, by Lindsay, and Railway Square by Marcus Clarke and Orchards. Possibilities are all about the city – and they are slighted by Building Surveyors who have the souls of louses.

Rain: yesterday, through the night, and all the day, heavy rain passing, slow rain, and partly clearing skies, and rain clouds heaping again and in the line hazing flares like great flames, rising and falling: yellow lightning and white suddenly out of the black of the night to show for an instant threading rain, and growing mirror pools through the murderous mud, and an imagination rioting against evil of terrible wounds and overwhelming misery, and heavy sodden great coats, numb cold fingers and desire dead.

67.

Turning in: In the morning early the attack taken up by the
Entry.52:
– through the Americans. Now word is of a weird map line, and a wonder on the whereabouts of the 27th men who passed Gury. In an excitement of advancing have the Americans forgotten a ‘Mopping up’ of their ground? At any rate they’ll fight: so tomorrow’s Battling may release them.

October 2

68.

Maps must await correcting. Yesterday away with Harold to Abbeville, and the day’s news all rumours unconfirmed. In Abbeville news of Cambrai and St. Quentin falling, and of troops closing on Lille. Divisional wires of touch being lost with the Boche in Flanders about Passchendaele, of the 3rd & 5th holding well and advancing, and of strong fighting by the Boche. Wires this morning tell of no definite lines, so maps must wait.

October 2

69.

Abbeville’s no "Digger City", pale-face locals, one decent eating-house and untidy streets.

Going in, Bus to Pont Remy, then walking, passing Epagnette, we had tea, at a dandy little house by the road, served by a dear old soul of vastness and smiles. Tea in a tiny little room of vivid old wall paper, with an amateur general: all the papers of France were about him and all the maps of the war, pencilling his maps, he made notes and cross notes: then he beamed on us, and turned the machine gun of his imaginings on us.

He gave us the "good oil": war would be over by October 31, and Australia would be ours again.

Met in Abbeville Eric G., Syd L. and Clive G.

A gem of a shop discovered, closed! in its window books of Barrie, Drinkwater, Brooke’s Collected Poetry – on its 2nd Impression, and books by the good novelists. Today Eric goes in with orders for the buying of the Drinkwater book.

Bomb wreckings shew the old decaying construction of some of Abbeville’s high shops: there is interest in almost every street, and some of the better preserved houses shew curious design and carving.

70.

Evening.

Late morning Tom mentioned a Y.M. Library at Ailly-le-Haut-Clocher: so tonight there with Harold, and Masefield’s "Shakespeare" brought back. A walk in the grey rain over high clear fields, tree clumps and stacks vague green silhouettes: all the day a thin sun has stood against growing clouds: tonight the rain.

Rumours grow of our going to Dieppe: today a letter from Commonwealth Bank so will have some money to back an application for a 24 hours leave to Rouen – if the tale is true.
Entry.53:
71.

Tonight to Fontaine: and a ‘bon’ night. In the half-light of the evening a doorway of the church, and the windows above it – a very beautiful design with flanking buttresses, offers a good piece for sketching.

For Coffee into a Farmhouse Estaminet, and a meeting there with three Diggers – one a 3rd Bn. lad – hat on the back of his head and black fine hair loose over his burnt forehead: the brilliant blue eyes, the Pan-like nose and lips riven in repose and white even teeth: tunic and shirt wide open, and a strong neck splendidly set on broad shoulders. Madame, a great fat

October 3

happy animal of about thirty became amourous of him. In the light of the fire and a dull yellow lamp, a shadowed roof and gleaming pewter on the mantel and Bottle shelves, a picture from Rabelais, or a drawing by Lindsay.

In the morning the sky clearing, in the afternoon the sun: along the canal banks there with Walpole’s "Fortitude", and a laying down by the unused lock gates: an afternoon of dreaming – the long song of the tumbling water, tall leaning sentinel trees and their lovlier reflections, and the sun in a sky of blue patched thinly with small clouds. tonight the skies clear, blackly blue and sparsely starr’d.

The yarning came up of the 27th Div. omitting its "mopping up" by Bullecourt, and of the situation saved by the 3rd & 5th. The 3rd Lad tells the tale of one of their "Mopper up’s". From a dugout, fighting, the Boche were all killed and fighting a losing game, surrender wasn’t accepted. Pass some of the following wave:

"Well, you’re a cruel bastard!"

"B--! I’m the ‘Mopper up".

72.

Arnie in tells of 2nd Div. attacking and of strong opposition: 21 O. 651 O.R. to 5 tonight through Cages. Big fighting will be along their lines. Battling will extend from Cambrai to St. Quentin. The whippets out today in the 2nd’s attack but the opening not yet for the Cavalry Corps behind. No rain in the skies: tomorrow!
Entry.54:
73.

A morning at Fontaine, sketching the Doorway discovered last night: Madame (the lover of the
Entry.55:
Bn. lad) so happy seeing my book, after an issue of Cognac, filled straight from the bottle my glass of coffee.

A wire after tea –

"G.H.Q. reports the surrender of Turkey A.A.A. Address all concerned."

Spoke to George tonight of a D.H.Q. paper – and find him enthusiastic, so will get on to the working out: Tomorrow will see McCubbin and enlist his pen.

The second have been hardly fighting about Montrebban and tonight wire of prisoners is 28 O. 1128 O.R..

74.

Mail: letter from Mrs. H. and this on Butler Yeats essay on "The Modern Woman",

"I received a book from you about a fortnight ago (and read it). His views on women I thought rather amusing!"

And I thought they were so ‘bon’!
Entry.56:
75.

Ken away at Samer, the whole darned crowd of Maps where only three can work, moping and full of bloody irritation, and Tom warring against one of ‘G’s letters solemnly reading the day’s filthy rag. There’s not an iota of work in, and the whole crowd of us are tied. Yesterday morning I left early with Ken to Fontaine without seeing T. & received back at midday a resentful glow full of vague blasted accusations.

Give him a box of maps and a pile of coloured pencils and he’s happy.

76.

Evening:

Tea over and away along the Canal Town Path with Harold to L’Etoile: and a long enjoyed yarning of appreciation of beauty: enjoyed, as it meant attempt at definings to explain the quality and meaning of beauty, and its terrible fascination. Walks in the evening with H. are good – he’ll yarn on and on of forest surveys, rivers in flood and forded, and terrible storms amongst the trees: and awhile I’ll listen and awhile will wonder on his beautiful build, on books and on the dark colours of the water and the slow coming gold of the trees.

Mail: from T.B.C. "The Title" – read and Barbusse’s "We Others".
Entry.57:
77.

Two going mad together. Hate that grows and grows presses in and in on one, he the while with his hurt hand held in his tunic, intently turning and changing the plans and maps of our one folio. Twice in the morning he has changed and changed the placing of maps, and he held long silence while we dully sit neither reading or writing: then open a book and turning comes the asking to re-roll some old come-bying maps. A self confessed idealist and an obvious Dreamer! At Sylvestre Cappel Jim blatantly licking with him spoke of Balzac and France’s satire "Penguin Island" and Tom vaguely laughing confessed his Idealism, and his vague blue eyes and intent manner proclaim the dreamer. Coming to his turn for a home trip, he turned it down – telling Col. Viny he wanted to do a bit more! Then here a week ago he was to go before a fake board: he beat them and remains. It is that three years of the ruling of Maps and the Division have so excluding all else obsessed him and now rules him: all his reading is of German Divisions, of their methods of attack and their militarism: all his care is to hold from us all word of our stunts and our Division doings. ‘G" will

October 7

talk openly of some old action, & Tom will silently criticise their so doing, and forbid us all mention of any military doing: even when we are preparing maps of objectives, referring to them they are – ‘Those maps we were doing’ and if more precision is needed "those maps marked with the coloured pencils!"

The evil influence of the wholly good!

78.

Evening.

A letter posted to T.B.C. for Arthur Symons latest – "Cities, Sea Coasts and Islands", Bell’s "Potboilers" and J.C. Squires "Poems", 1st Series. This afternoon out with Harold along the Tow Path to L’Etoile, and to the hill by it – on the map "Camp de Caeser", commanding all the country about, and a part of the valley of the Somme, the hill’s crest encircled by a great banking of earth: its cup grown widely with great beeches, and a rarely beautiful undergrowth of Hazels: each tree trunk darkly clear, and the whole ground deep and evenly carpeted with the dead leaves of years passing. A great madden brown carpet and trees beautiful as great growths of maiden hair fern, the under growth vividly green, the tall trees that hide compleately the sky yellowing and changing to clear gold: still the full splendid reds and tawny golds are to come: then the old mound encircled road will be magnificent with the ‘troubled splendours’ of Autumn.

Back in Long a door to door seeking a billet, and one found by the Chateau: Madame is old and full of chuckling charm, and a quaint amusement at our conversational attempts. Eric today to Blighty.

"The Title" read, and enjoyed: full of the comedy of the moment, and of obvious satire, a rather weak note as the introduction in the third act of the imposter "Straight". The book of Barbusse – "We Others" a collection of small tales – tales of love and pity exquisitely told, and of the beauty only possible in the writings of the French and Russians.
Entry.58:
79.

Last night called at McCubbin’s Billet and tackled him about some sketchings for our rag (the only so far appealing title is "The Dud") found him ready with the offer, and "of course I can only do stuff like ‘Inf. through Peronne’, or such stuff". Then saw George, and after Charlie M.: he to find for us prices of publishing from his printer cousin. Saw Geoff today and from him a sketch and the promise of some written stuff. Major promises G. some contrib..

 Letter to Mother: no mail.

October 8, 9

80.

"Days dead are dark: the days to be a flame of wonder and of promise, and great cries,

"Of travelling people reach me – I must rise."

J. Drinkwater’s "The Fires of God" has not to do with "The Dud" (?) but is from the better knowing of Harold. A great poem and of a beauty almost of Thompson.
Entry.59:
81.

Today marking the G.O.C.’s map, White comes up, and with his even fixed smile attempts his usual dictating of the line’s position: according to definite information I fixed it: scrupulously careful to take no land from the Boche that was not ours. As usual he attempted the taking of towns still theirs. Then passing unnecessary orders to line Col. Ross’s map, he left. Then he returned: "You are in No. 4 along by the Chateau?"

"Yes, sir!"

"Then you’ve crashed! I want the billet for an officer of the O.A.C.: there are plenty of other billets in the village!"

So tonight we’re away from our comfortable home, back in the Hotel de Ville in the marbled plaster Committee Room.

As a souvenir, this pasting a general order.

The Englander crows! and asserts his own ridiculous militarism.
Entry.60:
82.

No Mail. This morning passing from the Chateau, McCubbin called me into his Billet: yarning & he shewed me an unfinished canvas of a road from Corbie, a great passing cloud of dirt from passing lorries: by the roads side a tank, Motor Ambulances in the background, and a looming observation baloon rising. The skies colour and painting force, the dust clouds full of hazing impression, and a tree good in its suggestion: but a picture of great attempt & no achievement.

Casually he mentioned, talking of printing, the cost of £50 for the 10th Field’s paper! Is it "Requescat"?

80.

There has been today an argumenting on the utter failure of the British – and the Division people too – in their dealing with Brothels and V.D. amongst the troops. Still brothels are "out of Bounds", and it has remained for one woman – Miss E.A. Rout – to show the rational way: Ken, hearing the argument, and coming into it, told of her making application officially to Corps for their support. The result? No knowing, but there’s guessing!

81.

Later.

Midday to the Chateau, found the maps line altered, and deep advancings by the French

October 10

towards Laon and along the Lines to N.E. Rheims, so no altering of maps: Then tonight!

G’s orderly in . Tom in: then out two minutes later "just came inside for a few moments Frank!" and I went in with a wonder if the roof were to fall. Cpl. Wertheim from before the Line map (that I’d altered according to the paper) asked if I’d altered this?

"Yes, sir!"

"And did you alter the one in the Chateau?"

"No Sir" – and I went on – "someone had already altered it to far beyond the line’s position" – turned slightly, and saw Cpl. White by him! Then he came forward, in full assurance of a point gained, and with his damned smile – "Oh the alterations were from the French official in the village!"

Tom pointed out he’d mistaken the town gained for one ten miles further into the Boche line – but White was quite certain: "Other names followed a sequence in the French wire, so that is correct!" Maj. Christy "Oh, of course it must be!"

Cpl. Wertheim: Well we’ll see the wire in the morning.

Then Tom and myself down to the French P.O. & a reading through the wire. The victory is ours: but beyond the allowing back of White’s gains. White has won by his insulting manner. He has fallen over himself in his anxiety to "Bow" to the G.O.C. & Col. Ross. But he’ll be in the next Birthday Dishonours and he’ll wear the D.S.O. Ribbon. Then there’ll be quiet again.
Entry.61:
82.

Yesterday’s sequel. White’s gains retaken by the Boche, and the line only steadily advancing. Now on all Maps a poster – Line correct to – at – By? A moral victory!

83.

In the afternoon to Ailly le Haut Clocher for a bath: new change again.

By the Baths the Bn. H.Q. of 6th Bn.: their flag of scarlet and purple against the backing of a white plaster farmhouse: abutting it, a red brick wall and arched gateway greatly overgrown with the Virginia creeper – deeply red and gold brilliance and a white seen through grey woven clouds.

Tom away at 10 last night – for a day to the Base! for a day? for a rest?
Entry.62:
84.

Out in the night, faint rain, an exquisitively cool breeze, a dully luminous cloud sky and darkness in the village.

A Reading of Vol. 11 of Sinister St.: Michael buys Pater and a wounderful edition of Boccacio & Rabelais and Straparola: and Guy Hazlewood sells his old books to pay their debts. One explanation of MacKenzie’s facination is his compleat Book love.

85.

To the Estaminet by the Church with H. Three tables there, a drinking crowd and great musick of voices, laughter and a discordant gramophone. H. Only will drink coffee and talk survey.

For a night with Les and Mac – Les with his black silk hair, and gleaming eyes that vanish as he smiles and Mac of the honey gold hair and affectedly sleepy eyes – in a smoke hazed estaminet crowded with deep drinking diggers, yarning of books and of men, tolerant of all, and greatly loving the whole splendid crowd.

As aliens drinking coffee, as aliens passing, came in two of the A.P.M.s staff, and they brought the presence of dull resentment.

October 12

85.

The only haven is in self and in silence: selfishness so perfect that nothing may touch it, silence so deep that nothing may penetrate it.

"He travels the fastest who travels alone": God, then I travel alone, and in silence. God, but I’m tired! and my thanks for Keats. He at least knows.

Wrapped lightly in a brown blanket, safety pinned and stark on a stretcher, a carrying party and a shallow grave. Snow was a huddled shape in his clayey grave at Dickebusch, a gabbled sermon by a Padre who has no realisation of the body he commits to the soil; and dull illiterate sods filling in the grave. And the rain again, and another dark cross heading another grave. My heart aches and a drowsy numbness holds my sense, the whole day has held nothing that justifies it, yet I hate myself and am filled with blasphemy, they drink from gleaming filled glasses and laugh, and I am dead, a few feet of soil and another grave, an exultation and a ship that slowly moves through the blue water of the Harbour – gold arrows

from the sun setting, filled the waving arms of the water the day we left – a hellish wind shriek and a beautify body of nerve and trembling flesh pulped to terrible bloody meat, and in there life after that sees the bodies horror? and a grouping around of men who blindly see all that remains of the man they knew.

And so to bed: God, but my soul’s dead.
Entry.63:
86.

To the flat hills that look out over the valley and its string of wooded lagoons.

Round and about the straight banked canal winding under the yellowing trees: whiffs of white mist low on the ground.

A grey sky and a pale white moon and cold, cold still air.

Darkness grows and the mist deepens: then only a deepening yellow blue of the trees tips, and growing shadows: a moon silvering the canal thread, and on the ploughed hill the dark of night and the slow silence broken only by the sad cry of a bird, and the broken whisper of a shuddering breeze.

October 13

87.

Geoff H. in tonight: then around to his billet. He shewed me a great collection of enveloped papers – long essays in verse of warr and warr’s trappings. And I thought again of a recounting in Artzebasheff’s "Breaking Point" when he tells of an aspiring parvenue who shews to him his soul, and eagerly awaits confirmation of his dreamed greatness.

Today’s mail tell of Germany’s reply – accepting Wilson’s terms – diplomatically debasing herself. Madame is excited: but …

88.

Some great books.

MacKenzie, "Sinister St."

Joyce, "Portrait of the Artist"

Artzebasheff’s "Breaking Point"

Hugo’s "Les Miserables"

France’s, "Thais"

Pater’s "Imaginary Portraits"

Conrad’s "Shadow Line"

Masefield’s "Gallipoli"

Clarke’s "Vengeance of Fionn"

Butler’s "Way of All Flesh"

Benvenuto Cellini’s ‘Diary’

Burke’s "Limehouse Nights"

Hardy’s "Jude the Obscure"

Meredith’s "Ordeal of R. Fevrel

Apulius "Golden Asse" and "Simplicissimus"

Vachell’s "Quinnys"

Shaw’s "Love Among the Artists"

Barrie’s "Half Hours"

Stevenson’s "St. Ives"

Flaubert, Mdlle. de Maupin

No mail today
Entry.64:
89.

"This in Dinkum! – No, ‘its 
Dinkum
’! I tell you!"

"I tell you he played on that violin for four – hours till he’d only one string left!" … "an’ the wolves were afraid!"

A sky of curious dappled clouds and a vague white light of the moon behind them: to Cocquerel, and the while H. endlessly talking of …? Once it was bulls, and I was thinking of the note from Beaumonts from the Ambulance last night: "The Budded Branch" by R. Nichol, then it was rabbits and goannas, and the wonder was of working afterwards with Vin.

There’ll be lonliness afterward – lonliness that I’ll hold with work: Harry is dead, and he’d have kept me to the mark. Gerald? Will our friendship survive the years between? and Court? The damned amusing point is that if I go back to Lindsay I’ll be a mistrusted intruder.

From the C.B. today word of £5 being sent through Div. Paymaster. Will settle with T.B.C. and get hold of "The Golden Cockerel" and "The Budded Branch" and "New Paths", a cardigan will set me then for the winter. Laon ours today!
Entry.65:
90.

Alone to Ailly le Haut Clocher: across the high meadow of quiet lovely greens and ploughed purple earth, a silver and blue smoke clouded sky, and a splendid cleanness in the cold air. A Bath and a change at the Divisional Baths, and back to Long, back to tea, and a ridiculous argument of sculptured memorials. Ken defends the Prince Albert Memorial!!

Ken once taught "Art" in one of Victoria’s Technical Colleges: dislikes Agustus Johns on Jim’s word: is amusedly tolerant of impressionism and perpetually wears the carnival impression of a festive Methodist.

Mail, from Paris, the two books of Herbert French: two books to keep till a golden day for reading by the old Roman Camp by L’Etoile.

Good advancings in Belgium, and Lille well saliented: today comes Wilson’s reply to the Boche note: the war still grows.

Wertheim G.S.O. III, last night, in a generous mood – talked of books and writers. Came in one of the A.P.M.’s runners, saluted, he delivered his word, saluted, and retired. The tale came: we were alongside one of the Guard Regiments: a Guard runner came across with a special message for the Col.
Entry.66:
He entered the dugout, saluted the Capt., and asked permission to address the Col.: gained, he saluted, he saluted the Col. and handed his wire, and waited. There was no reply. He saluted: saluted then the Capt. and retired. Two minutes passed, and a Digger’s head came through the dugout door. "What bloody fine dugouts these Brigs. 
do
 have! Is the Col. in Dig.?"

91.

Out of the mist, above the village with the moon, silvered sky behind it, the great ship shape of the church, a door opens goldly to the shadowed street, and empties a dozen yarning diggers to the night. The musick of laughter and voices, rich awhile slowly dies: a girl passed, a shadow across the road. The mists slowly curl and deepen, the ribbons of gold from shadowed windows pass, and the last light of the Chateau’s high windows suddenly dies to the darkness, "and leaves the world to silence and to me."
Entry.67:
92.

An Australian mail in, and letters from Mother of July 31, and Aug. 25, from Betty Aug. 23, and from Mat a dear note Aug. 22. Letters too from "Dear Aunt Fanny", full of "your darling Mother" and "your dear Dad" – and from the Rev. Barbour, a reply to my letter from St. Sylvestre Cappel.

Low has been killed! Mother wrote of Mrs. Stafford calling – her first outing since hearing: Mat in his letter confirms it.

Credit note through, and three letters written: to "The Export Manager, T.B.C., 926: to Beaumont 19: and to Mayhew 2 – part settling of the books he set aside in 1917. Met him this time while in London, and found him most charming over the matter – where I’d half expected having to reseign the books back to him, asked him too after a S.H. copy of Fletcher’s "Architecture" book. Beaumont for "New Paths" and the middle edition of "The Budded Branch": the Blue and Gold "Golden Cockerel" reluctantly passed with the Cuala Books. Asked T.B.C. after the Cuala "Responsibilities" and the deluxe "Posthumous Swinburne" book.

Reading today "Brickwork", but relief from a summary reading of "The Battle of the Marne" of French’s – up in the attick by one of the roof fanlights.

A night of silver and cold blue, and autumn frost in the air. A wire tonight of a landing at Ostende, and ours. Tomorrow, Lille?
Entry.68:
93.

From T.B.C. a three book parcel: Symons "Cities, Sea Coasts and Islands", Clive Bell’s "Potboilers", and J.C. Squire’s Poems. Pot Boilers good if only for "Art and War" and "Ibsen".

A gloomy grey day, but mid-morning a wire in of cavalry by Bruges: Ostende occupied, and Thielt and Lille ours.

94.

Casually yarning at tea, the idea came of a way of a part rebuilding of French and Belgium cities. The Educational scheme is all-embracing: then why not enrol all Architects, Builders and Engineers, and men of the allied Arts, and set them to a reconstruction – set the reconstruction as a study on a grand scale, to be actually carried out. To rebuild part of wounderful France! there’d be in it something worth while.

Tomorrow read Brickwork again. Tonight J.C. Squires.

October 19

95.

Morning completed four sketched pages for a Christmas Card: tonight, ten enveloped for posting.

Nearing Zeebrugge and Roubaix and Tourcoing captured, an advance continuing.
Entry.69:
96.

A Library list.

"Sinister St.", Vol. II & "Sylvia Scarlett": "Architecture", Lethaby. "Poems of Love and Earth", J. Drinkwater: "Poetry of H. French", two volumes. "Poems", J.C. Squire: "Pot Boilers", Clive Bell, "Building Construction", Mitchell & Cities, Sea Coasts and Islands of Symons, 
and
 Keats, a week ago a night spent in a pasting and mending of its loose pages.

Thinking seriously of applying for a Rouen leave, with Dieppe called in on the way. Symons and Bell both mention a St. Remy in their two books: but fancy rather Bell refers to the St. Remy in the Mezieres sheet – which is absurd seeing he refers to Rheims being in ruin while St. Remy stands.
Entry.70:
97.

Tom away this morning on his first Blighty leave: a day of quiet. Morning, saw Geoff, now G.S.O. III with green tabs exchanged for the scarlet, and easily obtained his sanction for a Rouen application: so put it in. Afternoon at McCubbin’s billet. Then to his ‘studio’ – a small half glass room at the back of the house, a great wardrobe and circular bath – littered well with colours its only furniture: on the hard walls several canvases, and

October 20

one above others good, a street of Peronne: half the road is clear for traffick, half a heaping of debris from smashed houses: dragged to the debris, a dead horse – a shape suggested – and along the cleared road a line of close touching Boche guns. Haze of the sun over the foreground, and dust above the road, far far away thin column of deeper grey-blue finger fantastically up through the turning sky. A dozen small sketches, mere notes of swift impressions, are really good: these he intends to work from later: but already enlarging one to a great canvas of the Mt. St. Quentin stunt, the rich suggestiveness of the sketch is lost in the painting, a long yarning till the grey of the clouds filled the room, then back to the Mairie.

98.

From "Estaminet Tales"

(a) A Dear Young Flapper, "a Nymph of the sidelong glance" stops an Aussy in the ‘Strand’ – but, "Go away woman! we hear lectures about you!"

(b) Of the "Sentimental bloke", "Where did that one go to Herbert?" Three shells fell on the chorus, and one, "Stop, I’m wounded! No, only gassed!"

October 21

99.

Writing opposite, with his head down, Ken is startlingly like Lindsay, even his features and stiff curling hair about the thin patching of his crown, the immediate reminding is of Best’s "Crown of Thorns" cartoon of Lindsay. Mother’s last letter told of Best’s death of consumption.

Afternoon away to Ailly alone for a walk and a bath, grey clouds and silver lagoons in the valley amid yellow-brown trees wreathed in strands of mist. At the baths two teams of the 6th Bn. from an Australian Rules game: a splendid picture, steam from the showers and bathing men, and about others stripping from blue shorts and close black and red, and purple and red guernseys, men of close knit build, newly marched. Who could paint it: Orpen? Lindsay would splendidly draw it and Johns.

Passed to McCubbin today Bell’s "Pot Boilers" and to George E. "The Title".

At Pozieres last May, 17, met El-Banks, he rather defiantly mentioned an engagement with an Irish girl he’d met on leave. Today Harold receiving a letter from him hears of his marriage.

A walk tonight half-way to L’Etoile with H. along the road, with its great shadowing of trees.
Entry.71:
100.

A Digger in the Estaminet tonight, "Give us some Pomme d’Terres!", and with the air of an ultimatum, "There’s all 
my
 French!"

October 23

101

Morning to Cocquerel, and a sketch made of the Church-Chapel and the road swinging round it. Back at Long in Maps, Ken tells of Charlie Mitchell having reply from his printer cousin, so around to the Chateau. For the printing and paper, 300 copies, £5, for the blocks £4, so away to A.D.M.S. and a good yarning with George.

Afternoon away with Harold to Longpre, and from Lofty with the first contrib. of a "Have one of our Blighties" add. Rich in Drawings, but damnably poor in articles.

A long morning: early to George E. with Lofty’s note, and another loose yarning: in the afternoon George had been to the Pay Dept. and roped in 75 orders: and while yarning "Gas" chips in order 25. Then saw W. Priestly, he is enthusiastic: talking he suggested "The Heavy Hour" for title, or the "Bon Ton" and Cosmopolitan, but H.H. is really good, so will probably adopt it. Then Geoff suggested following numbers to take as a subject one of the Brigades and further promised rep. articles from each Brigade and a note of his own – probably on "The German of Today and Yesterday seen by an I.O.", or a "Note on Common Sense", introducing Wilson’s 14 points.

Then to McCubbin’s Billet. Mac had well dined, I heard, so the yarning a general damning of the ‘Anglias’ and a golden rioting with Australia’s future.

He to design some covers today.

So probably "The Dud: Strictly Neutral" becomes "The Heavy Hour", appropriate as stuff is ironically "The Heavy Hour" to Bns.

102.

Paris dangled in front of me: and much mortal strain following. But I’ll leave Paris till the Opera opens, and stick to the original application for two days Rouen.

Rumours of our shortly leaving here, for Le Treport on the Coast: so will try tomorrow for a full day trip to the Abbey church of St. Riquir. Gerrong in Abbeville two days ago, brought back a guide book, "Peeps into Picardy" full of photographs of a wounderful Cathedral at St. Riquir dating from the fine period of Gothick. Possibly will go along with McCubbin or Geoff Hankins.

103.

No mail: payed this afternoon, drawing 42 Francs, so letters to
Entry.72:
T.B.C. settlement, and to Beaumonts & Mayhew posted.

A note written to Jim Scott asking for the support of one of his sketches to go by D.R.L.S.

This Today as an item for "The Heavy Hour", "Outpost",

Passing clouds haze the grey moons light

And White flares arch and die;

Machine Guns chatter away on the right

And the winds a cold shuddering sigh

And my brain strives wearily towards thought

and dead phantoms pass as the flares arch down:

And the grey moon fades, and I am naught

But two eyes that peer through the dark.

October 24

104.

A street of shadows, and and silhouettes against a vague far sky, and the cold paleness of a full moon, and the sound of far voices.

Oh the wild wild woodbines

The cold cold woodbines

Are making a mess of the Hun!

- Laughter and ribaldry 

on "Inky Pinky Parley vous"

The Aussies are having a – right time

Keeping the Tommies in the line

Inky Pinky Parley Vous.

105

Morning away with McCubbin to St. Ricquer , and walking there and back, a long day enjoyed.

A richly ornate Cathedral, a quiet clean little villiage and a day of pale sunlight and clean winds.

Harold back to his unit.

October 26, 28

106.

Two Crest Titles: Boche: ‘Gott Mit Uns". Tommy "Aussy’s with us!"

Another cold grey day: pass for Rouen forwarded on to Corps. No mail, and a sketch for "The Heavy Hour" of Villers Bret. Church ruin: morning at McCubbin’s billet.

A Fire in one of the places in "G" and a yarning of old rhum evening – of Estaminet immortal – "Pig’s life" of Dranoutre, "Bully Beef" of Sailey, and all the other old terrible names.

Capt. Wertheim’s contrib.. a dull jingoist’s jingleistic string of verses – which will pass!

Now the arguings on the Peace Parties of England: damn! I’ll along to discuss trifles with Mac.

October 28

107.

Afternoon away to Ailly: awhile watching match between 6th Bn. H.Q. and Brigade, then a Bath and by Lorry back to Long. Morning a blue sky, and the first sun for a week, afternoon silver clouds broken with deep and silver blues, and the valley clear of mists, forests and ploughed ground chequerings of splendid colour and a while through clouds a patch of sunlight would colour to formal lines of fine far away forests and gild clustered haystacks.

Mail, first T.B.C. for months.

October 29

108.

An evening spent about a fire, yarning of old rhum issues, with deep mental sighs over the present drought, and of the Divl. Concert Party. The crowd back from Pont Remy, tell of a good show, and recount good tales.

An item, Monash meets Haig, in Little Lens, two years ‘Apres la Guerre’!

M. "What! Haig!" handshake & whisper.

H. "No! I’m broke myself!"

M. One thing I often wondered at – how did you get your Austrns. home!

M. "Oh that was easy! Let me see! First we sent over the 4th Div., they’re all married now and settled down. Then the 5th, they’re good too. Then the 2nd – they’re all over S. Aus. and then of course the 2nd. Quite easy!

H. But, let me see! I thought you had 5 Divisions!

M. (vaguely) Five! Good God! I haven’t relieved the 1st yet!!!

109.

Mac to London on leave, so "The Heavy Hour" to wait his coming 
back
 home.

Yarning with G. two days ago, regretted not having Gilbert’s "Songs of a Campaign" – "it’d make a good item for a review page!"

G. with a hundred chuckles produced the book: so a long night I spent slaving with no result at a "review". Then yesterday the idea came of an Essay note on Ypres – "The Death of Ypres", a foolscap page of manuscript completed and the subject is good.

No mail today: Rouen leave probably 5 to 8 November, D.V. Letter commenced to Mother & one posted to Aunt Louie, so far no letters from her since leave, if Charlie has been killed it will be a most terrible thing for her – but then the lie will never be given to her created legends.

Whisperings in the air of a Dance with the W.A.A.C.s from Pont Remy.
Entry.73:
110.

The sun all day, and afternoon to Ailly, a bath and a haircut at the 6th Bn.

Today another added to the company of the two of the Engineers: a
Entry.74: Bn. S.B. At the baths a week ago singled him from the bathing crowd, and today saw him closely again, in shorts for a practice match, with his tunic on, and on the left arm the white band and the red S.B., there is a keener beauty about his build and his expression is more severe than the loose Engineer.
Entry.75:
111.

Evening. A wire from D.H.Q. – Armistice signed on satisfactory terms with Turkey at 1200 today.

This is Dinkum! – and prisoners taken by the Italians number to 33000, which taken with the last three days rumours of their sueing for Peace seems a tangible sign of her breaking up.

The afternoon spent on a sketch for "The Hour" – "Romance" – the old formal Chateau of Villers Bret. Ken handed in his contrib. – a pencil sketch of the Church, Hotel-de-Ville and Lock Gates taken from along the Canal.

Mail, a dear letter from Mother, dated
Entry.76:
Pass through from Corps, for Rouen leave Nov. 5th-8th, and 60 Francs to do it in.

Ends October with vague rumourings of the line again. North with General Birdwood’s Army.

112.

Conversation of Mary Queen of Scots: yarning of Holyrood. Mr. Sorrel recounted the tale of Marie bathing in white wine and milk. "White wine – that’s vin Blonk Mar!" and the tragedy of Marie’s extravagance overwhelmed George. No pay drawn last week, the days have been empty of ‘vin Blanc’ – so a blackballing of M’s.
Entry.77:
113.

Early afternoon, a message through from Corps, of Austria having signed a Peace with Italy. Now Germany’s turn comes.

A parcel from home, sox, and a bon cake – and with Cocoa from Comforts issued today, a promised supper tonight.
