George tells of a Bayeau arrangement, "Beaucoup promenade – beaucoup beer – beaucoup coal!" A sandbag of coal – two buckets of beer, so an encore.

Says a Digger – "Christ! yesterday Johnno, today Austria – I can see a chap in a week’s time in hospital!"

114.

A yarning about the fire that turned somehow to Bairnsfather having interpreted warr to a great part of England – that their realisation of war came from his cartoons. Mac & self held the floor against the crowd, who hardly defended his position as an ‘artist’. So a yarning to today’s writers of warr, and the days books of warr, Mac holding nothing has been produced of world value and of permanent interest as a true reflex. But he ignores Masefield’s Gallipoli – Letters of a Soldier – these principally and others,

November 1, 2

holding that 
the
 book of war will not be written till a half centuary has passed, yet even though this is true, it will be merely a compleat book after the school of Carlyle or Prescott – perhaps it may even equal Hugo’s "Waterloo" or "Les Miserables", yet war will be as soullessly written there, as in old histories, and today’s diaries and journals will be the true reflex. So to a telling of items of a Patrol report.

"The prisoner would not come. So we brought his papers."

Of the bomb slid into a pocket, and of 40 prisoners leaving the line thinning to 30 by supports.

Warr is only temporally realised by those passing through it, and half forgotten after, but for a phantasmorgorical impression of a dream.
Entry.78:
115.

Morning, a parade at 9.30, and a march towards Longpre, then to the left, and squad drill for an hour on the flat between the lagoons, a whole Corps on parade, and a band of A.P.M. raiders through the village of the area.

No Mail.

G. at Midday – "So Geoff giving you a contrib. for that mag. of yours, Frank! – I’m – if I can read it, too bloody intelligent!"

Now the rumour of an early move has grown to a certainty: there’ll be big attacks now in the North, and a winter campaign for the A.I.F., and perhaps some more vested insults from Sir Conan Doyle.

The trip to Rouen a toss-up. Coming down the hill with Mac, a sky of silver and vague misted mauve through multi-ting’d branches of leafless trees.
Entry.79:
116.

Midmorning. Mac and Ken still writing, and Ken R. back from Rome leave yesterday monolouging of Italy.

"It’ll do me on the Italian Front – it’s a bonne Guerre there – Fact! – they hang their washing on the barbed wire, and notices are up "This part of the river reserved for Austrians bathing! – "This for Italians."

Read till late in the night "Poems of Today" and enjoyed the collection, especially Stevensons and Chambers rare piece and columns, more than ever before.

Two from C.R.A. just away, after a yarning of drawings: one promises some sketches from the Artillery’s side, for "The Hour", the other a satire piece.
Entry.80:
117.

Morning at 10.30 to a Requiem Mass to the Australian Dead at the Church of Long, celebrated by Monsignor the Bishop of Amiens, with George E. and Mac, in the organ gallery. The – delivered – badly and disappointingly by Padre, and concluding the Mass, from the Cataflaque and its 11th Bn. guard, a short splendid cameo speech from the Bishop.

A Luncheon at the Curie’s house afterwards: Padre Berkeley presented me to him (Bishop) later. A man of wounderful presence, a Prince of the Church, the courtly gentleman, and the splendidly robed Priest.

Evening, and a sudden agony of excitement over the rumour of the Boche surrendering. A rumour only: and a rumour accentuated by a Corps order cancelling the 6th’s move 48 hours.

Yesterday the idea of Rouen leave lost.

Arrived, reinforcing "Maps", Arthur Cox of the 8th Bn. seeming a man after Tom’s and Ken’s hearts, quietly old, with perhaps Ken’s ideas of Art – a medium for the better presenting to others minds of Morality and Ethics. Big issues of Maps in: to be issued.

Damn!

Address delivered on 4th November 1918, by Monseigneur the Bishop of Amiens in the Church of Long (Somme) in memory of Australian Officers, N.C.O’s and Men fallen on the Battlefield.

My General, officers, Non-Commissioned Officers and men of the 1st Australian Division.

After the words that have fallen but a few moments ago from the Pulpit of Truth, and from the lips of one of your own Chaplains and knowing little of your beautiful language it behoves me to keep silent, but if I gave no utterance to my thoughts as this impressive ceremony is nearing its conclusion I would fail in the fulfilment of a triple duty which my conscience dictates to me that of prayer, that of gratefulness, that of admiration. Duty of prayer for your numerous dead resting in peace in my land of Picardy and on the borders of the Somme.

Duty of gratefulness for the liberation of my Diocese delivered from the enemy’s yoke. Duty of admiration for your heroism which has placed you in the foremost rank amongst the bravest in this unique war.

Together we have prayed for your dead, and their immortal souls have appeared before God who has judged them. As human praise expires on the brinks of their tombs we are powerless to grant them the Glory which they have a right to. For that reason we supplicate the Lord, in offering him the sacrifice of Jesus Christ to give them a reward worth of their emulation – may He make them perfectly Saintly and Beautiful, that they may have a right, one and all, without delay to an eternal Crown and glorious Immortality.

As Bishop of Amiens I owe you and your Illustrious Dead my heartfelt thanks because the land of my Diocese has been your Field of Battle and you have delivered it by the sacrifice of your blood.

During the painful days of the invasion you have made a rampart of your Breast which you shielded and saved the last shred of my territory. Later, when Victory at last we smile upon our arms the Australian Army distinguished itself by the audacity of its attack, by its utter disregard of Death, by the doggedness as well as by the rapidity of its advances.

In the name of my Clergy and of my people, I offer you my heartfelt gratitude and admiration.

Gentlemen, your Dead were great men and amongst the most Illustrious, because they obeyed the highest inspirations. Why did you leave your far away Australia, because of your sentiments of loyalty towards the British Empire, whose Banner has protected the British and development of your country, its existence, its economic future and its civilisation, for these were in jeopardy as well as the destinies of France. It was necessary to snatch from German Military violence the hegemony of the World, for that reason you left your shores and crossed oceans, for the Honour of your Country and for its future.

It takes blood to cement the foundation of a country, and you could not refuse it in the World War to the cause of Christianity. You have indeed lavished it with a Saintly generosity and in so doing have written a most glorious page in the history of Australia.

On the fields of battle far away from your homes, the love of your Country became stronger in your hearts and children who, during the coming centuries will grow up in your homes and schools will learn through your great deeds, the reason of Patriotism. They will not be able to pronounce your names without speaking of the Towns, Villages, Table-lands, Ridges and Valleys of the Somme where you have gathered the laurels of Immortality.

Indissoluble links unite our two Nations; a link of prayer because we will piously keep the Tombs of your heroes, a link of Friendship because the Freedom of my Diocese has cost you so much blood, a link of mutual admiration because the hearts of our soldiers, Australian and French, beat with the same love, with the same enthusiasm for the Saintly Cause whose final triumph will assure the futures and development of our two countries under the eyes of God who has blessed our arms.

November 4, 5

118.

To T.B.C. for Masefield’s two newly announced books – "St. George The Dragon" prose, and "A Poem and Two Plays", for "The Adventures of Tyl Ulenspiegel" newly translated from the Flemish, and a booklet from Beaumonts "Barbed Wire" 1/6. Today’s T.L.S. announces early publishing of Dyson’s book of Warr Drawings.

Parcel for posting to Mrs. H., Symon’s book of "City" essays.

November 5

119.

Morning rain and greyness. On Sunday afternoon – 3rd, to match between Emma Gees and Engineers – yellow guernseys and Blue, multi coloured sox, and vivid green ground, later away along the Canal to Caisens Camp at L’Etoile, nearing it, a great Fijian Corps on the crest of the hill, brown, purple and red, against a grey high sky, and the trees half barren of leaves, and a new carpeting of wet red greatly patched with pale yellow and the blue green of ground ivy, and vagabond winds and slant falling leaves in little clusters.

The lovliest tree of autumn in the Chateau grounds, a great flame of scarlett and vivid gold, a flame in the sun, and sullen beauty in the rain.

November 5, 6

120.

Morning’s rumour of 500 villiages liberated to the French & Belgians, late night’s wire of a big assault progressing favourably.

121.

Mail – from C.W.B., "The Budded Branch" and "New Paths": the works of Nichols printed and produced 
beautifully
 well, the coloured decorative pieces of A.E. Rice making the pages as beautiful as any I’ve seen. Their New Catalogue announces new works of "The Russian Ballet and Ballet Plates". Later will have "The Golden Cockerel".

All day long the rain, grey cloud passing deeply steel blue behind the trees dead of their leaves.

Tom back from leave.
Entry.81:
122.

Reg Little from Davis & Oriole, a Bill!!! And on the strength of moving up tomorrow a pound sent over to C.W.B. for "The Golden Cockerel" – to be sent to Mrs. H., and then cometh a wire rumour of the move cancelled 24 hours, allowing the maps to conform with the advance, called for Café et Benediction, and the last 5 F. to George for Vin Blanc!

123.

In the evening late: a 5 Blank entry. A night spent with one Payne of the 3rd A.S.C. Coy. in the
Entry.82:
Coy. A.S.C. in an Estaminet drinking and yarning. Each evening lately, for a while I have gone to the estaminet by the Church, to drink coffee and watch and listen to Emma Gees yarning and drinking. Tonight a half dozen drinks and Payne yarning of Ypres – the time last year and its memories of Hill Five comes and , then of the year before – Flers and Longeval. "Flewers" says Payne and half-drunk he confesses. "I don’t mind telling you Dig, I wasn’t born in Australia, but I was there 9 years before I enlisted, and I’m going back there!" My reply! "Too bloody true Dig", so passes a night yarning with an unknown, who typifying the A.I.F. spirit, arguing to pay for each drink, brings again one of the old Ambulance Rabelaisian nights to life – in a dingy brown room with the monotonous song of rain and sudden showers outside.

"And so to bed": Oh Mr. Pepys, I would yarn with you tonight, of the sadness of the years that dull the colour of the candle light on wide shallow glassed champagne – so to bed. Good old Alan Oodle of the lined intricate drawings, and a discovery – the secret of impressionistic liberation – the
Entry.83:
realising of the style James Joyce uses in the "Portrait of an Artist" – so to write you must be sad after a lost night of vin blanc drinking, with a hundred pens to write as they pass the million impressions that awake in the mind.

November 7

124. 8.30 p.m.

The day’s been full of rumours: early they started, from Abbeville a whispered word of a Boche Reserve crowd leaving Berlin for the W. Front: at 2 p.m. a wire through – should a German officer bearing the white Flag present himself on the British Front, he was to be received and conducted to D.H.Q.: G.H.Q. were to be notified immediately, and the paper was late: it arrived at 4 – and the heading confirmed the early morning rumour, and at 6 a thin rumour came of a peace signed, it grew and at 7 Abbeville – including the was holding high – an Armistice was signed at 5 p.m. to come into force tomorrow at 3. Tension so high the big Digger rang up Mac at Corps, they’re "watching and waiting too".

To leave Long in the morning, G. and Maps by lorry to St. Souplet – through Amiens, Albert, Bapaume, Cambrai and Le Cateau. In December ’16 across the long Flers valley we watched the two towers of Bapaume. In April 17 we could see from the hill by Hermies the Town of Cambrai.

Passed down towards Longpre, a company band led by the
Entry.84:
in the half light of the night, and the people of Long flocked out, exited and happy. We watched them from the Balcony of the Mairie.

St. Souplet

November 9

125.

Rain from Cambrai to Le Cateau and in the dark arrived at St. Souplet. G.Q. and Maps in a great cold stone floored room, once an old Boche Hospital (?).

126.

Evening: and a half dozen yarning in a semi-circle about a fire built in a high copper like fitting in the room’s centre, while outside the drone of passing squadrons, and a keen frost in the air. Tonight the 2nd Brig. to go into line: possibilities of a stunt close following into the retreating Boche. Word is good of advancing on all fronts, though today no wires have come through. Outside a Tommy Sig. Officer, the Bulletin of some splendid stage managing of resolution and rebel demands in Germany – all to back for England’s Peace
Entry.85:
Party, Germany’s apparently honourable desire for peace. A reply from Foch has gone to Germany, for acceptance of his terms by 8 a.m., Monday.

In the afternoon walking about St. Souplet with Mac and Arthur and Blink. Civilians, for the most part old men and women, though there are others occupy, the compleation of the villiage’s warr’d houses. This retreat was hasty: in the churchyard his new graves with the bodies barely earth covered lie open, their hasty name boards by the hole: in one grave a coffin with neither earth nor covering. Three new A.I.F. graves – two of the 115 H. Bty. and one of the 113rd.

Tome is reading "The Cloister and the Hearth", the first English novel I’ve seen him tackle: all his other readings have been old French novels, and Boche captured phamplets.
Entry.86:
127.

Last night came rumour again, and early this morning confirmation at 11 a.m., hostilities cease, no fraternisation, and the line reached to be fortified and held. So far the Brigades have not taken over any front: the move will probably be tomorrow: we to Asvesnes as H.Q.
Entry.87:
128.

Asvesnes cut out! and so to Long. Mail in tonight, a great woolly muffler from Grandma, expected from last month’s mail from Mother.

Tonight to finish an impromptu whisky-celebration.

The reading finished today of Ian Hay’s "Knight on Wheels" – a whimsical light yarn of invention and love.

November 12

129.

Morning, back from St. Martin, while there waiting for dinner, some notes on trip from Long to St. Souplet.

Amiens midday, and an awakening city, workmen about the station repairing walls and jagged roofings: trains in the yards and about the station and a crowd newly arrived invading: and lines of Gharries waiting, shops opening and civilian traffick with military. Arrived the day’s French Paper, and with its news, great excitement laughing, the ‘Daily Mail’ followed, then drinks.

Albert passed and Pozieres: and the old Pozieres-Maulte line blown away and a heaping of distorted and fantastick iron, with burnt out frameworks of an old train crowning the mound. Passing the Cemetary on the Left side, small evenly ranged crosses still compleat, and crowning all the 4th Bn. cross and the

November 12

1st Div. in the cement basing, with a shrapnel shell’s packing, and one of its struts loosened.

Bapaume’s old ruin dead of ghosts, quiet in the greyness of the day.

In the dark through Cambrai, and against the deep of the sky, black silhouette of tall chimneys and high buildings, with yellow unsecured windows, passing headlights of motors shew walls jagged by shells, and comfortable whole homes and tall windows heavily curtained.

Curses loud and deep from a Tommy Artillery Capt. on the Albert-Bapaume Road. We held the road’s centre, and in a Ford he tried to pass us: the lorry swerved and beat him back, curses to pull the lorrie’s wire to the driver – and the wire was missing! Twice he nearly passed us & twice we beat him back – then his rush – "Get out of the Damn way!" half past, and an helicon blow out!

Coldly and without emotion we left him, cursing scarlettly standing in the then rain while a tyre was warr’d on by his driver.

130.

A "Billy Book" of Low’s Cartoons of Hughes arrived with yesterday’s mail. -- ?
Entry.88:
131.

Morning along to St. Martin and on the roads mending and repairing, all England Labour Corps – dull unlovely marionettes without life or vitality, and in the afternoon, endlessly passing to water their heavy draught horses I watched a crowd of the R.G.A. and on splendid mounts they were still the dull brothers of the old Labour men.

Tomorrow or the day following to Bohain to entrain: says rumour, to the Rhine! No!! to Marseille to enship!!! Damn! we are as in a dream, afraid to awake and wonder on the long strung-out transports and the Ocean winds for the South. So we sleep instead, and pass the tale along of the Crown Prince’s assassignation !

Cold, and a smoke barrage up!

November 13

132.

A great sky of clear blue, hazed about the horizon, a full sun and over the hill slow winds. Morning met a French lad of 14, salving about old trenches, and whistling awhile the Marseillaise: and a morning about the hills with him to old M.G. possies, to the tune of his laughter and quick talk. He was France, but without the blue Porter’s
Entry.89:
cap and trousers, instead he wore old ragged trousers, and a newly torn military shirt, Boche boots and a tight woollen cap. I asked him if he spoke German, and his blue eyes laughed to a happy "Non m’sieur! Boche? Non m’sieur."

Tomorrow to Bohain and a hundred rumours of Garrison work on the Rhine!

No mail today!
Entry.90:
Bohain

133.

But they won’t believe, and perhaps it is as well: Barbusse has written ‘warr’ stories of its red trappings, naked and terrible in the mud and the night. "Under Fire" read tonight by a hot good fire in a comfortably warm’d room, read to the end of "The 
Relief
 Return" in a growing wonder at its dull truth. "I’ve killed 20 of them in the candle" he grouts; "in the big dug-out by the tunnel, mon vieux, there are some like crumbs of metal bread."

Vigil was with them too: his body wasn’t touched, but they found him with his head completely flattened out, flat as a pancake, and huge – as big as 
that
. And the staff! God but its true –

"The liberal professions are not represented among those around me, some teachers are subalterns in the Coy. or Red Cross men. In the Regt. a Marist Brother is Sergt. in the Service de Sante: a professional tenor is cyclist despatch rider to the Major: "a gentleman of independent means", is Mess Corp. to the C.H.R. But here there is nothing of all that, we are fighting men, we others, and we include hardly any intellectuals, a man of the Arts or of wealth, its during the war we’ll have risked their faces only at the loopholes, unless in passing by, or under gold laced caps."

But there comes to mind the great exception – Alan Seeger, and the artist of "Letters of a Soldier", and one Arnold Drysdale Savage!

November 15

134.

Three days following of an early spring sun and skies. Morning looking for some sketch to make, but the only beauty of Bohain is the men crowding the streets and two squares, and billetted along whole rows of whole houses. A long flowing along all the streets of the A.I.F. and sprinklings of Tommies and Jacks, a great two-up school where a bomb wrecked building has been cleared away, by the stone skeleton of the burnt Mairie, and a hundred groups yarning, changing and passing each second.

The Beauty of these villiages of France, is rarely in
Entry.91:
their churches, Mairies or big Chateaus: but it quietly and unconsciously survives in the colours of their tiled and slated roofs, and the long ragged perspective of brick and stone gables, highly pitched roofs, and mild colouring of weather stained and sunned tiles. Bohain’s church is a great high and wide brick and stone and cemented building, splendidly wide and high in the nave and compleated by a great circling apse, but as soulless as a Joe Gardner’s factory or store. Now hundreds of France’s flags cluster about the altar, & decorate the nave and aisles: candles burn before side altars, and great bunches of fresh flowers are everywhere.

Mail today, two from Mother, one from Betty, and a note from Angus, and I’ll have the Lindsay Book and Hilders and "Art in Australia".

Mother on "Ghutz"

"Dear but what a funny name! so greedy!" and Bett on Bapaume Hotel de Ville,

"What a lovely Hotel."
Entry.92:
135.

Cold day: payed, T.B.C. Boyd’s "Salvage" & Post. Swinburne.
Entry.93:
136.

Back from "The Sentimental Bloke" opening show with Maurie B.: a good show and an evening enjoyed.

A cold crisp night and a moon lit clouded sky: in the small narrow streets, the flickering frozen candle points of yellow and great shadows and crowds about small tables, and along the roads a tide of men yarning and laughing, broken whistled bars of "Chu Chin Chou", and shouted names ringing with the iron of shod boots on the ragged cobbles.

Yesterday a note via the Ambulance from Aussy of a coming Christmas No. and doubled prizes. Will send in a verse and sketch of George’s, "What is a Brasserie Dig!" 

Mortimer coming back for the advance on the Rhine stunt, if the railways clear by the
Entry.94:
the marching will be cut out. Our objective between Cologne and Coblenz.

Posted home Boyd’s "Salvage", Louis Hughes book and "New Paths".

Today arrived four Diggers from a Boche prison camp, ragged in their old uniforms, weak, with a terrible quietness in their manner and yarning.

In the Aussy Y.M.C.A. Reading room, a dozen Diggers, a great fire, and about it Bohain’s ragged Kiddies. It was by Poublot!
Entry.95:
137.

Compleated printing of the Bishop of Amiens speech after the Requiem Mass at Long on Nov. 4, for records, to be signed.

Wrote to T.B.C. for new sketch book, pencils, Deutsch book, and ‘Sappho’ from Florentine Press. Posted to Aussy verse and sketch. Christmas cards to home, and letter to Mayhew.

Moving day after tomorrow – for Asvesnes.
Entry.96:
138.

All the morning the sun: and I dotted the I’s and squared the capitals of the Bishop’s address, in the afternoon out, and a great mist clouded the streets – a cold grey deep mist that hid the sun. Met Urn by H.Q. and a yarning with him.

A night about the fire, Mortimer yarning of his listening post experience: then Mac on Lady Diana Manners to Maurie and self, and so to bed. No mail.

November 21

139.

Afternoon to M.G. H.Q. and 3rd Bde.: their oil is good – of our not moving to Germany – Belgium our objective. Billy Hughes is dead , and has had a row with Monash, and meeting Rube Palmer by the Mairie, hear of the vile plot to dump the A.I.F. fifty miles up, in "No Man’s Land". Mac explains this,

"Son – if Germany jibs at the signing, well they’ll just turn around and say – ‘Y’ won’t? Right! Come, on Doug," will say Foch – "we’ll bring the Aussies up and Fritz von ‘ll sign anything.

November 23

Cartignies

140.

‘Maps’ in a building on their own, a great square, low ceilin’d room, three casement windows opening on the Grand Place: G opposite and Q away in the corner. Old beds, straw, and a good fireplace.

Bohain left early after the 2nd Brigade and Cartignies reached early in the afternoon.

This morning Batt. following Battalion the whole of the
Entry.97:
Bde. have marched through the square. The General came out from his Billet and took the salute alone. It is great to watch as the troops pass, the groups of French and Belgian civilians, and to watch their faces and gestures. Two of Poublot’s kiddies invaded Maps windows to throw kisses with most exquisite charm. Then they begged cigarettes for papa, and danced for pennies as for sovereigns.

The Ambulance passed, and yarned awhile with Addy and some others: the unit seems new, with the old men in the transport and tent sub.

141.

A dream: an hour to dress, and the first changing to old clothes after the war, a dark grey suit, & in place of the old black knitted tie, a navy blue, and a blue silk handkerchief worn in the sleeve, 2 oclock and I’d to meet Mr. Thompson at some theatre, and already half an

November 23

hour late, in a hotel marble vestibule, a meeting with Clive Goyder – the first chap I’d met since coming home, and a yarning with him of lost Rouen leave, and his last Blighty. Meeting across some green Miss Sharpe & Sybil, and then talking of a Benediction Rhum punch they had ready, and to prove the presence of the Benediction they pointed down a muddy road by Flers to where two urchins played ball with the empty bottle.

Strangely this afternoon coming from Asvesnes met Clive F. At a small Café there, cocoa with Eric, Mac and two Pioneers. Eric tells of our destination - Louvain!

November 24

142.

Two bullocks, rope rein driven, drawing a long limbering wagon, drawing in its turn a small convoy of push carts & wheeled boxes, and a trailing party of all-aged people, the women in black shawls and all assorted dresses, and the men & boys in Khaki, blue porter caps, and old rolled mufflers, and propped amongst some tumbled gear and straw in the long wagon, two old old women epitomising the whole tragedy of war.

And then 
passed
 past them as they drew into the square, the 10th Batt., with a bravely borne colour standard and a full band playing.
Entry.98: The 2nd Bde. through in the morning and in the afternoon the 3rd. Billetted above us a party of the
Entry.99:
Batt., in the dirty cold attic, and below in the tiled small rooms.

A mail of a single letter form Aunt Louie: from sheer genius she posted some months ago the Moore book and a cake – addressed to ‘Maps’ A.I.F.
Entry.100:
Solre-le-Chateau

143.

Midday arrived at out Billet for a week in the Grand Place of Solre, the
Entry.101:
Bde. following, marching straight to the lovely old turretted tower that stands full in the road’s centre, where it turns towards Beaumont.

Mail – Invoice from T.B.C. for ‘Legend of Tyl ’ and "Barbed Wire".
Entry.102:
144.

A sketch, commenced yesterday, completed this afternoon of the Mairie, the fine old tower, and the lorries of the square.

The Grand Place a great school of lorries, with a workshop established in the centre, a lathe and tool shop in the bandstand.

Last night yarn around the fire, of the certainty of the building being mined! .. tonight with Geoff from C.R.E. of The South Sea Battle, and later of Gold Mines and Mining.

Mail, still no T.L.S. and one letter from Mrs. H.

Tonight we billet ourselves in the top floor of the bay we’re working in. A grey day.
Entry.103:
145.

A grey rain mist in the morning, and in the early afternoon a pale sun and a blue thin clouded sky: and in the rare sunlight, the colours of the old masonry of the tower, and the slating of its turrets and dormer broken spine richly diverse and beautiful. Basil B. hears from some local ancient that it is of the 15 cent. and of Spanish design. But it is purely Flemish – a strongly built tower, richly and fantastically turretted.

The Church itself is disappointing where a comely beauty is expected, dull gilded Rococco altars and badly coloured Plaster saints cluster in the cold shadows, and stare vacantly at the crudely glassed windows. All its beauty is the tower, and for all its fantasy, the old Church of St. Vaast of Bailleul more directly appeals.

To the Ambulance this morning, and met there Jimmy Stanger – Adjt. of the 3rd. Jimmy greeted me as ‘Pat’ and I’d almost forgotten the name was mine – was in a hurry but shewed me his room with the crush around tonight. "Will y’ have a glass of wine?" – his batman’s a good soldier tho’, and the bottle was empty.

Afterwards down to where Solve’s station was & where the mangled steel framework of broken trucks line the long strung ditch where the line was once: shells and parts of shells of all calibres, and long shell baskets litter the yard amongst the tangled ruin of a hundred trucks. Seemingly one end of an ammunition train has been mined, which has set off each truck along the whole line. The papers report two of Brussels station going up in the same way – with no notification from the Boche of the mine prisons.

146.

Tonight’s rumour: By February 1919, all 1915 men will be in transport for home. This week a report is to go through of all men of the first six months of 15.

No mail: letters written to T.B.C. and to Aunt Louie: asked her to send me Morris’s "The Hollow Land" and Stephen’s "Hill of Vision".

November 28.

146.

Rain mists and rain all the day. Tonight with K. to the Sent. Blokes showing in the hall on the second floor of the Mairie by the Tower. No show: no Concert Party shew, but an impromptu programme by the diggers with no lights but the moving ends of cigarettes and the occasional flare of a match. For a while choruses, ending in "The Good Ship Yakky, Yakky d’la! Then the lights, and again darkness. Cat calls and mild
Entry.104:
wit, and great following waves of laughter. Then some officers left. "Fall in the Officers!" Quick March!! "Anzac you’re forcing me!" ending in a protesting shriek: some more officers leave. "Carry on Serg. Major!" and "Pack all your troubles".

So back to H.Q. and a sweating on mail! Leave Solre within the next four days, for some great Chateau (that is more magnificent after each whisper) 10 kilos from Charleroi.
Entry.105:
147.

Morning to Beaumont. A lorry caught just outside the villiage to near Leugnies, and a walk of about 3 kilos across the valley of the Hantes to the villiage. An ordinary little villiage built on the hill, narrow stepped cobble streets, gaily behung with great Black gold and red flags. Coffee with a Pioneer, then alone to the old Tower gateway through the walls to the South of the town overlooking the Hantes. A shell ruin, with staircase to the top still solid, and in the shell four or five old fire places with traces about of old carving and tracing. So on the way to Solre again and a lorry picked up by Grandrice by the Border. In it two Belgian lads, thick-set Brown skinned pagans, with wonderfully impressioned eyes.

George across this afternoon and yarning of Charleroi, and Namur and Brussels. Our next possy at Presles, near Chatelet.
Entry.106:
148.

Rumours: our final objective Cologne. Billy Hughes has accepted an offer from Japan to transport within four months of peace signing, the whole A.I.F. and the King is to pass Solre tomorrow!

Afternoon to C.R.A. and yarning with one of the draftsmen, a yarning of places and drawings, and subjects and Lindsay and the Australians – the last subject from a notice in the Nov. 26 "Times" of a Dominion exhibition at the Burlington House.

"What we all hope is that Australia, Canada, N.Z. and S.A. will each in turn have a distinctive Art of its own. The Colony which becomes a Dominion must also become a society, a civilization, with its own ways of thinking and feeling, and these must express themselves in Art & in Literature."

And this in the face of an actual proof of a national and most individualistic difference – a proof over three years – of the vast differences between the various dominions and the English troops. It was the Times L.S.’s cry that Leon Gellert was nearer akin to the American
Entry.107:
Alan Seeger (I forget the exact sentence ending bit) then to the English Subaltern Poet, they complained of his "luminosity" and of his treatment of his subject.

And the prose – the prose of the expressed pious hope in a patronising manner will remain England’s attitude towards the Dominions, perhaps till Wilson delivers his interpretation of "The Freedom of the Seas".

C.R.A.’s billet a finely designed modern house, deliberately despoiled by the Boche, panelling torn out and door architecture, doors wrenched, and carved marble mantles fire blackened and chipp’d.

A cold bitter dull day.

Cabled today for £15 against the thin chance of a leave to Brussels and Antwerp.

149.
Entry.108:
Solre le Chateau

A cold grey afternoon, snow seeming near.

An hour ago the men of the first two months of 1915 drawn up in the square, then marched away towards the Station end of the town. A while later they returned without their packs.

Tom left midday, for Bohain, and so to England.
Entry.109:
150.

A grey woven sky and no sun. Awhile in the morning and in the afternoon to the hedged fields across from Solre, to where the Brigade have their football field. Playing both in the morning and afternoon, teams of the 3rd and 2nd – the third in white underpant drawers and guernseys and the 2nd in blue shorts and green and purple.

Afternoon game I watched for an hour, one of the 3rd forwards – Hill, from N.Z.: he recalled the beauty of Jake Hines, but finer in his build and more nervely muscled, he’s awakened again the wondering over .

Morning, coming down the road over the hill, a Digger, a great horse, and a girl, she was modelled and painted by Rubens: she wore only a white woollen sweater, a white woollen cap and tight breeches and canvas leggings, she was as splendidly vital animal I’ve seen – so superbly built as a Flemish plough mare.

Still no T.B.C. parcel or T.L.S., only a note from Harris – of Aussy – of thanks for V.B. sketch of the church tower ruin: no mention of the verse or joke drawing.

Last night a celebration – Rhum hot and Port Wine!

December 3, 4

151.

Afternoon in the blown fine rain, to the Bois de Madame – a forest on a hill of sullen purples and deep shadows.

From T.B.C. "Barbed Wire" & "Tyl Ulenspiegel", ¼ read, and all enjoyed. Wrote for "Principles of Planning Builds" and Barrie’s book of playlets.
Entry.110:
152.

First teams of the 2nd and 3rd Batts. played this afternoon, in a vile field, mudded from two games played there in the morning, and in a grey cold mist. A solid game from beginning to end, and two teams well matched. The 3rd game, 3-0, with four of their balls forced by the
Entry.112:
153.

Influenza, or some damned break up. This afternoon to the field, but only ragged teams, into Coy. & Batt. games.
Entry.113:
154.

11.30 a.m. Andy Betts in a while ago, tells of Charleroi – "Oh, a bloody lovely place – a second Paris, and bigger than Amiens – and women! I had five and the bonniest little piece ever! – an’ gin and cream puffs and every bloody thing!"

This and more, answering my, "What sort of a city is it?" 

No definite date for moving, but probably about 11th.

Mail on
Entry.114:
from Mother, receipt and catalogue from Davis & Oriole, and from T.B.C. letter answered and posted this morning asked for Country Life book of monuments and memorials.

Grey and misty, and the square crowded about with the Division’s last move.

December 9

155.

Yesterday clear colour skies and a sun: today a greyness over all. Yesterday morning with Arthur C. to Sivry, where the 13th Bde. are billetted: in the afternoon with Ken to the 1st Bn. ground, there the game was against the Engineers, the Engineers game. Kempsey of the 1st played a great game. (Remember him with Jake, and R. Binney of the 2nd F. Coy. E.)

154.

Standing by the mantle two letters written, to Aunt Louie and Heffer of Cambridge for Catalogue. Afternoon with George B., Andy and George to
Entry.115: Batt.’s ground where they played the
Entry.116:
the 9th’s game.

Mail, from Aunt L., Morris’s "Hollow Land" & Stephen’s "Hill of Vision" and T.L.S.

Met Toby at the ground and Bill F. and others, Frank at the Ambulance after.

Frank S. back from an Eng. leave spent half in Dublin and Killarney, tells of a great holiday, charming people, and Killarney as an experience in Green.

Mac finished reading Tyl Ulenspiegel. I’ll post it home, a bonser book and I’ll watch for De Coster!
Entry.117:
155.

Morning’s spent wondering on dinner – cold meat and potatoes: afternoon waiting mail, then tea: and then three hours dwelling on bed. Days that were wasting, that are leaving deepening sediments of boredom over our lives.

Today, dull and raining: payed: no mail: and three hours to bed!

Letters posted this afternoon to Kensington School of Art and Liverpool University of Architecture. Morning, from the newly arrived Divisional Educational O. and hear from him, that if application is made for a six months course at one of England’s schools, there is a good possibility of leave being granted, and the course payed for.

Later, a four page letter written to Mat – and burnt! built the fire up and mooded by it, till I remembered the pictures in the Mairie, so across with Arthur, and a Bath amongst Battalion men, and a boredom lost. The same programme as of three nights ago, but a house audience of diggers and Flemings.
Entry.118:
156.

For five minutes in the early afternoon, through the gray tumbling cloud sky, a lovely honey-coloured light over the square, bathing in a faint gold the tower and the close narrow houses, then grayness again, and across the empty playing fields a blown rain haze in great smokey gusts.
Entry.119:
157.

Interminable rain: yesterday in a haze and on a field of mud the third played the fourth, 11-0. Today all practices and games off.

Mail, an old parcel from home. A week since, and with two exceptions "Q" staff changed, new men from Batt. and one from the 2nd F. Coy Engineers. Met him going to cookhouse, and remembered him then as an old Grammarian from the ‘shell’, a short yarning yesterday: he’s a type to cultivate.

Yarning with George C. tonight, he tells of G.H.Q. forbidding Miss C. Rout her work in Paris and threatening her hotel ‘out of bounds’ and a placing there of a M.P. guard. So turns the damnable machine of England’s Army people, on the one woman who has grappled rationally with the V.D. problem. The Army’s idea of wiping out V.D. is to install at H.Q. Barracks a Blue Light Establishment, and a dull M.O. who dully ‘lectures’ incoming troops with statistics of the cities rottenness.
Entry.120:
188.

‘Maps’ packed for moving tomorrow morning: Maps G and Q for Presles wether in the villiage or in the Chateau a kilo from it there’s no certainty, tho’ chances are against the villiage.

Blue patches through the

December 14

great cloudy sky, and away from Solre, a clear light over the countryside, and sudden patchings of a golden colour over far hedged fields, the Brigade moves tomorrow, so no football.

Mail, a brief note from A.I.F. Educational H.Q. of no information, and from Corps – Aussy – a note from Harris asking for a sketch about the verse I sent in from Bohain.

George B. today promoted – Serg. to Educational Officer! Ken R., Staff Sgt. in charge of G. and Bill A. Staff Sgt. Q., Kirchler and Larry Corps, and ‘Maps’ still remains modestly in the background as four privates.

To finish the evening, to the Pictures, there a few days back, one "For France" – a bon piece of unintentional satire. The scene on the Meuse, and in the nick of time arrives to save from the an Artist’s daughter and her Murkan F.C. lover, a squadron of Tommies. The Corps News sheet 10 in tonight prints a Commonwealth Cable on Demobilisation:

The troops will return as units under their own officers. The Battalions, regiments and batteries will be divided into halves, the first-coming half containing as many men as possible meriting preferential treatment according to the priority list, as follows:-

Firstly, married soldiers, with preference according to the number of their children, length of service, and guaranteed employment in Australia: secondly, single soldiers of long service, with guaranteed employment; thirdly, other single men according to length of service. Commonwealth Cable.

What an orgy of sentiment and flag wagging and tearing emotion they’ll give to the people of Australia – what a noble sight "these damned Soldiers" will make for the people, and how grateful they’ll be at our reception!
